PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Education
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 28 citizens) and Robertson (from 32 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled;

should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned shows-
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumer Electronics Industry: Colour Televisions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows our concern of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations on Certain Consumer Electronics Equipment and Components; particularly the Colour Television Industry, and the effect it will have on employment in this Industry if accepted.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should take action to protect the employment and technological expertise possessed in this Industry. The action taken should be that of a Global Quota System maintaining the present 95 per cent of the market to Australian Manufacturers and an increase in the local content factor to at least 55 per cent on large screen (20 '' and above) colour televisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office, Southgate Shopping Complex
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully request:

That the establishment of a non-official Post office at Southgate Shopping be not proceeded with and that the existing non-official Post Office at Sylvania and Sylvania Heights be upgraded to provide a greater range of services to the Public. We oppose the establishment of a non-official Post Office at Southgate Shopping Complex on the following grounds:
(1) Expenditure by Australia Post on capital costs is not warranted including rental of $40,000 per annum.
(2) Inconvenience to residents in Sylvania heights, particularly the aged population who would have a long walk to and from the proposed Southgate Complex .
The establishment of a large drop box facility at Southgate, along with stamp sales from the Newsagency would serve the Central Area at virtually no cost to Australia Post.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the offer which he claims he made in the debate in the Senate last night to make available to selected members of the Opposition on a confidential basis the aide-memoire of his conversations with the judge. When did he make this offer and to whom does he claim to have made it? Will the Attorney-General table the aide-memoire, not on any confidential basis which would prevent action being taken if such were thought necessary, but in a form which, while protecting individual identity, provides an accurate record of what was actually said at the two meetings?

—I made the offer to the Opposition in the course of the debate last night. I had thought there had been some earlier communication from office to office but on checking I found that the matter that I discussed with the staff member concerned, because of a failure of communication on my part, had not been communicated during the latter part of the afternoon. I do not propose to repeat that offer, given the circumstances that have developed and the way in which the Opposition has behaved; nor do I propose to table the aide- memoire in any fashion, sanitised or otherwise, for all the reasons that I explained last night.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the recent decision of the Marcos Government to prevent Filipino poet , Cirilo Bautista, from attending Writers Week in Adelaide last week and part of this week-a decision which had been made on the basis of one of Bautista's poems published earlier this year as a tribute to the assassinated Opposition leader in the Philippines, Benigno Aquino. I ask the Minister whether it has been brought to his attention that a message of protest against this decision, directed at the Marcos Government, has been signed by over 30 leading writers from 12 countries who are currently in Adelaide. In the light of these actions, can the Minister say whether the Australian Government will be making representations to the Marcos Government in support of the poet Bautista and his right to leave the Philippines?

—I have seen Press reports that, as Senator Bolkus said, the Filipino poet Cirilo Bautista has been denied permission to leave the Philippines to attend Writers Week at the Adelaide Festival. The Department of Foreign Affairs provides assistance for one overseas participant to attend Writers Week. The Department's involvement extends only to the provision of an economy class return air fare. On the advice of the organisers of Writers Week, the Department had approved the provision of such a ticket to Mr Bautista in November 1983. Mr Hayden has advised me that he has asked our embassy in Manila to check out the details surrounding the Philippines Government's alleged refusal to allow Mr Bautista to attend Writers Week. Certainly, I expect it will be the subject of further representations to the Philippines Government once the circumstances of that refusal are known.

—I refer the Attorney-General to the case in 1974 when a Mr Ramon Sala, who was being held in custody pending deportation while police inquiries were continuing into other matters, was released at the direction of a former Federal Minister and had his passport returned so that he could leave Australia at a time of his own choosing. I ask: When did the Attorney-General speak to the former Minister? Did he see him alone? What did he say? Was any record made of the conversation?

—I spoke to the former Minister on, I think, one occasion about 10 days ago. I do not believe any formal record of that conversation was kept, apart from handwritten notes by me which I communicated immediately to Mr Andrew Menzies, a former senior officer of my Department, who was asked to pursue this investigation. I might add that a detailed response as to the Government's investigation of the Sala matter was given in writing to Mr Steele Hall half an hour before Question Time yesterday. In those circumstances I find it quite contemptible that Mr Hall should have used the opportunity available to him in Parliament yesterday, without any further reference to me yesterday afternoon, yesterday evening or today, to do what he did on that occasion; that is, to suggest that serious misconduct or impropriety of some form had occurred in 1974. The reality of that matter is otherwise. All the material available to me in the investigation carried out by my departmental officer when this matter first came to the Minister's attention about three weeks ago confirms that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the Attorney's attention to those parts of my question where I asked whether he saw him-that is, the former Federal Minister-alone. What did he say in reply to the Attorney's statements?
—What did he say in reply to my questions or my statements?
—What did he say to you?

—I will not tell Senator Messner what transpired in the course of a conversation aimed at eliciting a response of a former Minister to allegations made about him. I passed on the circumstances of those responses to the officer of my Department conducting the investigation in question, who reached the conclusion that the nature of the responses, as communicated by me, were entirely consistent with the course of events which, from other extrinsic evidence, and from other material gathered by the officer, he found to have been the case. I will not pursue every last Will-o'-the-wisp floated for reasons of ill motivation by the Opposition down every rabbit hole that Senator Messner or anyone else might try to dig for me.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware of the restrictions imposed by the South African Government on entry to and exit from South Africa? If so, can the Minister advise on the nature and extent of those restrictions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know all the details of entry and exit restrictions placed by the South African Government. In the last couple of days, in light of the discussion about the refusal of entry visas to two South African parliamentarians, certain information has come to light. For instance, the South African Government refuses exit visas to Bishop Desmond Tutu, who is a senior member of the Anglican community in South Africa. We all know that Winnie Mandela has been under a banning order at various times and has been refused permission to exit from South Africa. We know that the President of the South African Council of Sport, Mr Van der Horst, and the Head of the Christian Institute, Mr Beyers Naude, have been refused exit from South Africa. We know that the chances of any of the members of the black community in South Africa getting an exit permit are very slight. Certainly if they were going to criticise the South African Government they would get none. If they did get out and made critical speeches, they would not be allowed back.

ANSWER.PARA: Many organisations are not allowed entry to South Africa. In particular, a blanket ban has been imposed on all staff of the World Council of Churches. A World Council of Churches official, Mr Russell Rollason, has been granted a limited stay in South Africa; otherwise there is a blanket ban on all the members of that organisation. I am sure that, as we go through various details of what happens in that unfortunate country, we will find that the amount of banning of exit from and entry to that country is far more extensive than we would ever consider to be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: — I preface my question which is directed to the Minister for Veterans Affairs by making reference to the fact that the Repatriation Act does not permit legal practitioners to appear before the various tribunals that come under that Act. Is it not a fact that briefs are currently prepared for non- legal practitioners who appear on behalf of the Repatriation Commission and that those briefs are prepared by legal practitioners or personnel with legal education within a department? Is it the case that legally trained officers appear for the Repatriation Commission, contrary to the spirit of the Act, in appeals before the Repatriation Review Tribunal? For example, is the First Assistant Commissioner, Legal Services, in the proper and ordinary sense of the word a legal practitioner? Has he completed any recognised degrees of legal studies leading to a legal degree or award? Has he appeared for the Repatriation Commission in appeals before the Tribunal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin has raised the question of legal representation before the Repatriation Review Tribunal, a matter that does excite some concern from time to time when the Repatriation Commission takes advantage of its rights and obligations to have such legal representation before a final court of appeal . I remind Senator Macklin, as well as the Senate generally, that the Repatriation Commission makes these decisions based upon the legal argument and what it considers to be its legal responsibilities. This is not a matter for the Minister or for the Department. Because the Repatriation Commission is a statutory authority it is able to act in its own right and make its own value judgments about these matters without consultation with the government of the day or the Minister. In those circumstances, whatever private views I might have on the matter, it is not competent for me to express other than a personal view to the Repatriation Commission, which acts on its own authority and under the provisions of legislation which is the responsibility of this Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true, as Senator Macklin has suggested, that the First Assistant Secretary in the Legal Services Division and the Assistant Secretary have appeared before the RRT as advocates. I am advised that that happens from time to time because of the lack of suitable staff. That has not happened since November 1983 because, I understand, the Commission has found it necessary to engage legal representation on matters affecting legal interpretation. It believes that it has some responsibility to the Parliament to test these matters in the final court of appeal. As I have said before, many of these cases have taken 800 days to come before the Repatriation Review Tribunal and have run the gamut of all the determining processes.

If there were cases which had legal implications, I think the Parliament would be asking questions as to why the Commission failed to avail itself of adequate legal representation before the final court of appeal if it did not do so. Generally speaking, the Repatriation Commission does avail itself of that opportunity. In response to the specific question Senator Macklin asked, I am advised that in only 2 1/2 per cent of the cases before the Tribunal does the Repatriation Commission avail itself of legal representation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and concerns delays in processing applications for tertiary education assistance scheme allowances. In 1983 many students experienced long delays in having their applications processed, and delays appear to be occurring in some areas again this year. Can the Minister say what is the current situation in regard to the processing of TEAS applications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to report that, in contrast to the chaotic situation which I inherited last year from the former discredited Fraser Administration, the situation with regard to the administration of TEAS this year is considerably improved. The number of TEAS applications is up this year; in fact, I am advised it is higher by about 10 per cent than the number received in 1983. There are two main reasons for that. One is that our Government liberalised the family means test for eligibility for TEAS. The other, of course, is that the encouragement that our Government is giving to increased participation is having a marked effect and many more young people are seeking to enter higher education and are thus applying for TEAS. So there is a 10 per cent increase on the number of applications received last year. Despite this increase the administration is much more efficient.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that, as of mid-February, some 70 per cent of TEAS applications received had already been assessed. A new system of issuing the actual payment is reducing the average turn- around time by up to two weeks. Under new arrangements adopted by the Department of Finance it has been possible to reduce the waiting time between approval of the application and the first payment to two or three days. In previous years applicants have waited several weeks for their first payments. In Victoria the turnaround time is longer than it should be because of problems associated with the removal of computing facilities from one building to another. This is a temporary problem and my Department has assured me that the processing is now being speeded up. I have instructed the Department to give high priority to the processing of TEAS applications and every possible effort, including overtime and the use of additional staff, is being used to expedite payments to students.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer again to the Sala case. Was the former Minister involved in the decision to release Mr Sala and return his passport one of the twelve persons interviewed by Mr A. C. C . Menzies, who conducted the investigation for the Attorney-General? If not, why not? If not, did Mr Menzies have to rely on what the Attorney passed on to him of the former Minister's recollection of his actions at the time and other extrinsic evidence that the Minister mentioned today? Perhaps the Attorney- General in his answer would advise us of the nature of that other extrinsic evidence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated in answer to a previous question that I was the one who discussed the matter with the former Minister to seek his recollection and conveyed the content of that recollection to Mr Menzies who, to my knowledge, did not interview directly the former Minister in question. He was concerned, rather, to investigate the substance of the relevant departmental files and to investigate particularly the departmental and police personnel recorded in the file who had recorded various notations or who in other ways had participated in the original course of events.

ANSWER.PARA: The essence of the matter can be very simply described. Without going into all the detail of it-this case is, after all, 10 years old and there is no conclusion whatsoever that justifies any suggestion of illegality, impropriety or anything else of that order-what happened was simply that this gentleman, Mr Sala, who had been the subject of a court prosecution for taking money illegally out of Australia and for being in possession of a small quantity of drugs, was dealt with by the courts, and fined rather than imprisoned, but was kept in gaol for a period of days thereafter, without any outstanding charge existing against him, or with any imminent prospect of any other charge being laid. He was kept there pending deportation following a deportation order that had been made, it seems, as a routine precaution by the Department of Immigration and the relevant Minister some days earlier, pending the outcome of the court case. The matter was the subject of representations to the then Minister, who took the view, quite properly, in my view, that we do not run the kind of system of justice in Australia that justifies people being kept in gaol for open-ended periods pending deportation, and that if there were no outstanding charges against the man he ought to be allowed to leave the country.

The circumstances in which he left the country, by way of being given back his passport and buying his own ticket rather than being deported, occupy a further section of Mr Menzies' report to me. Those circumstances are simply as follows: It is quite common and routine practice for persons being deported to be given the option, if the circumstances are appropriate, to not incur taxpayers' expense but to go of their own free will. In this circumstance there was a question mark that had been raised about the validity of the particular passport that the person was holding, as to whether it may not have been a forgery. That matter was brought to the attention of the Minister, who took the view that the police had over four or five weeks to investigate that matter. The police failed to do so to the extent of having anything which would justify their apparently laying a charge against the person in question. Again, we did not operate in this country a system of keeping people in gaol on spec in the hope that some sort of evidence would turn up to justify a person's being the subject of further charge and detention in Australia, and under those circumstances he ought to be given his passport and allowed to leave.

I believe that a further consideration that was relevant-and in the recollection of the former Minister was a consideration, although he could not recall how much weight he had given to it-was that the gentleman in question appeared to have Spanish origins and that he had been the subject of disciplinary and police proceedings by the then Franco regime in Spain in 1974. He had suffered imprisonment-this had all been put in evidence during his court case-for a period during which time he had had his genitals smashed by the heel of a Spanish guard as a result of which he believed himself to be sterile and regarded himself as likely to be subjected to further pains and penalties were he to be sent back to Spain, which was, of course, the only option for him as a Spanish national if he were to be deported rather than allowed his passport. Under those circumstances that seems to have been another consideration that was the subject of representations, so far as people can remember, and that seems to have been a further matter of influence, although that would not have been enough by itself had there been enough hard evidence around to justify a charge at that time.

The files are noted with the comments of senior departmental officers in the Attorney-General's Department stating that they agreed with the course of action proposed by the Attorney-General. The matter as to the passport was the subject of a reference to the Department of Foreign Affairs to ascertain what would be the attitude of the country whose possible forged passport it was were he to be given back his passport in circumstances where it subsequently proved that it was a forgery. The file was also annotated with the response of the Foreign Affairs Department that in all the circumstances the country in question would appreciate that the decision taken was reasonable.

I have gone into a little detail on this matter, perhaps more than was necessary; certainly more than was really demanded by the question. I have done so because I think it is very important in these matters to demonstrate for the umpteenth time that simply because some disgruntled citizen around the place, for whatever motive, chooses to put some half-baked version of a story on the public record, to brief journalists about it and to set them going in a great surge of excitement, to get them asking questions and to get the Toorak Times to run the detail of the story-that publication is utterly without any pretension to morality in these matters-that is not enough to justify the sneers and smears and the innuendoes about particular individuals, the way in which this case was used so blatantly by Mr Hall yesterday and the way it is being used by the Opposition at Question Time today. I have nothing but contempt for those who use this material in this way. I believe Parliament as a whole ought to respond accordingly to these sorts of questions when they are raised in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry and Commerce seen the report that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is eliciting reaction to its proposal that Australia produce raw steel products for processing in various Asian countries as part of an international rationalisation of the industry? Does this indicate a further coming together of the thoughts and plans of top management in BHP and that of the Prime Minister during his recent China visit as to the future of the Australian steel industry? Can the Minister inform the Senate of any latest Government reflection or action in pursuance of these exciting possibilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The visit of the Prime Minister overseas, and particularly his visit to China, resulted in discussions with the Chinese Government about the possibility of some integration between the Australian steel industry and the Chinese steel industry. Following the return of the Prime Minister to Australia that matter was the subject of formal discussions with representatives of the steel industry and the iron ore industry in Australia. As a result of those discussions a joint working party has been set up between the Chinese Government and the Australian Government to examine the possibility of integration of those activities. That working party will be busy for the next month or two and will then report to both governments in respect of that possibility.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday at the seminar in Melbourne the Chairman of BHP, Sir James McNeill, in an address to the conference, referred to the question of there being some degree of integration of the Australian steel industry with the steel industry, such as it is, in various countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations. That statement by Sir James McNeill is a particularly welcome one inso- far as the Government is concerned. It is certainly related to the initiatives taken by the Prime Minister when in China and it is vitally relevant in terms of the Government's approach to trade and industry policy that all those possibilities be explored as vigorously as possible. It is very encouraging from the Government's point of view that, in a situation in which there is world overcapacity in steel, the initiative should be taken in Australia to look at the possible integration of steel industries in South East Asia and Australia as , in a sense, a parcel solution to that overcapacity problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was all looked at years ago.

—Of course it was all looked at years ago. I suppose the honourable senator will tell me next that BHP has been trading with China since 1891. That is true. The honourable senator has been sleeping in the Senate since 1961, as I understand it. But that does not mean that all these opportunities should not be explored as vigorously as possible, which is the point I was making. I think even Senator Rae would welcome a statement by the chairman of a company such as BHP which is indicative of an increasingly outward looking approach in Australian industry rather than the sort of introspective, inward looking approach which has been present for too many years and which has resulted from various policies of previous governments which have seen Australian manufacturing industry and productive capacity totally concentrated on satisfying a domestic market with very little emphasis on the importance of exports to this country. It is very welcome to see, particularly in an industry such as steel where, as I have said, there is world overcapacity, that within Australia initiatives are being taken in an outward looking way to try to overcome some of those problems and provide a better basis for the development of the industry both in Australia and in South East Asia generally.

—Will the Attorney-General table forthwith the report prepared by the former officer of his Department, Mr Menzies, who investigated allegations that a former Federal Minister had in 1974 improperly ordered the release of Mr Ramon Sala from detention and the return of his passport?
—Where have you been for the last 12 days?

—I think Senator Gietzelt's interjection has said it all; where indeed has Senator Boswell been? I have given an indication as to the content of that report. I will give consideration and ask the Government to give consideration to the question of the tabling of the full report.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that in 1982-83 the apprenticeship intake was the lowest for 10 years? What steps is the Government taking to increase the number of apprentices trained and so ensure both an adequate skilled work force and a secure future for more young people?
—I hope it is not a Dorothy Dix question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume points out, with his usually lucid degree of perception, that the question is what might be called a Dorothy Dix question. I congratulate him on that. Senator Zakharov gave me notice of this question because, unlike many other senators, I would not have at my finger tips details of the precise decline in the number of apprenticeship during 1981-82. I plead guilty to that. In 1981-82 there was a decline of 32 per cent in the apprenticeships intake. That has resulted, and of course will result, in a reduction in the supply of skilled labour for particular trades. The decline in the apprenticeship intake in 1981-82 was very much dictated by the recession at the time. I think there is very little doubt that in the environment of the recession employers were not keen to take on apprentices. Probably there was less demand for apprenticeship places than otherwise might have been expected. But, of course, the Government is concerned that as the economy recovers there will be adequate skilled apprentices and tradesmen available for the skilled work force to take part in the recovery and the restructuring of industry in Australia. Because of those concerns the Government has recently offered a package of incentive measures to employers to increase the attractiveness to them of apprentice recruiting.

ANSWER.PARA: The first thing the package includes-if I might just itemise it briefly-is the maintenance of the real value of assistance under the Commonwealth rebate for apprentice full time training scheme by increasing all rebates by 4.3 per cent. Secondly, a special tax exempt additional apprentice employment rebate of $1,500 is available to employers who increase their apprentice training effort. Employers will be paid that rebate for putting on additional apprentices. Specific action is also being taken under the package to encourage the increased recruitment of female apprentices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Senator Ryan will supply the details if necessary. Assistance to graduates of trade base pre-employment courses is available by way of a $750 tax exempt payment in respect of each graduate employed and subsequently indentured. Those measures contained in the package are in addition to other measures which the Government has taken in relation to technical and further education training . I also remind the Senate that the Government is addressing the question of labour market skills generally by a review of labour market programs which is being conducted under the direction of Mr Peter Kirby, currently a senior officer of the Victorian Government.

—My question is also directed to the Attorney-General. I preface it by pointing out that over the past four days of questioning the Attorney- General has assured the Senate that outside legal opinion and his own meetings with the judge referred to in the Age tapes have convinced him of the correctness of the judge's behaviour. Are there any grounds on which the Attorney-General could be regarded as having a possible conflict of interest in his dealings with this matter?
—Insofar as the question does not seek a legal opinion, I will allow it.

—The asking of the question does no more credit to the honourable senator than Mr Howard's contribution to the debate yesterday did credit to that gentleman. No, there is no foundation on which any reasonable person could possible come to the conclusion that there is any conflict of interest in this matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR INFANTS AND CHILDREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. It refers to programs of early intervention for intellectually and emotionally handicapped children. Is the Minister aware of the education program for infants and children-EPIC-in Victoria which has been a successful early intervention program for some years? Is it the intention of his Department to continue to assist the organisation operating this program?

—I am aware of the education program for infants and children which is called EPIC and which is conducted at the Phillip Institute of Technology at Bundoora in Victoria. It is an early intervention program for intellectually handicapped children. The Department of Social Security funds several such programs. We have been considering how far this sort of program is related to child care and how far it is related to education. It is most likely, I think, that the Commonwealth Schools Commission will take a major interest in programs which have an education focus, although it will probably not take responsibility for them until some time in 1985, if then. My colleague Senator Ryan may have something to say about that. In the meantime, we are continuing to support the program at the Phillip Institute of Technology through the Office of Child Care. In the next 12 months the grant will increase from $106,000 per annum to $151,700 per annum. EPIC has a very impressive record. Its success rate in the integration of its children into regular services has been remarkable in that 75 per cent of all EPIC graduates and 95 per cent of Down's syndrome children from this institute have gone on to make use of regular children's services in schools. I went to the centre a couple of years ago. I have seen its work. I have seen its early training videos. The encouragement the children are given to develop the full stretch of their physical and intellectual capacities is very impressive. I hope that the enthusiasm of the teachers, the researchers and the parents at this important centre continues. They will certainly have the support of this Government.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether he recalls that, when justifying the Government's decision to allow offices to be established in Australia for the African National Congress and the South West African People's Organisation, two organisations committed to violent change in South Africa, Mr Hayden said that their activities were 'legitimate and accorded with the operation of a free democratic society'. In addition, the Government has allowed individual ANC representatives to come to Australia for a month, as I understand it, to present their point of view with respect to current affairs in South Africa to the public of Australia. How was the proposed week-long visit to Australia by two moderate elected representatives, Messrs Durr and Rajab, different in principle? In what way does their visit not accord with the operation of a free and democratic society? Does the Minister further recall that a gallup poll conducted last year indicated that 62 per cent of the people said that trade between Australia and South Africa should be encouraged, 72 per cent said that official sporting contacts between the two countries should be encouraged, and 75 per cent wanted Qantas Airways Ltd to resume services between Australia and Johannesburg? In view of this significant public demonstration of feeling on this subject and in view of the fact that the Prime Minister is the champion of consensus and fairness and a person who desires to bring people together, I ask the Government to issue those visas immediately.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. It is clear that the honourable senator is giving information to the Senate. He is not asking a question, and as such he ought to be called to order and asked to question the Minister in the appropriate way.
—Order! A lot of information was given in the honourable senator's question, which has now been asked. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate to respond to the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been a member of the Senate for only 10 years now, but in the whole of my time here that is the most confused question I have heard. The first thing it confuses is Senator Jessop's alleged commitment to high principle . He supports his commitment to high principle by citing gallup polls as if the two questions were intimately connected. I am not the least surprised that the majority of Australians expressed the views which they expressed in those gallup polls, but to confuse those answers in the gallup poll with the sorts of arguments of high principle which the honourable senator began with seems to me to be bordering on the bizarre.

ANSWER.PARA: The second bizarre thing about the question, of course, is that it really should have been directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. If the honourable senator is asking me whether I recall what the Prime Minister recalled-and that is what he did ask-about what Mr Hayden said last year about these matters, I only have to answer no, I do not recall what the Prime Minister recalls about what Mr Hayden said last year. I am sorry, I have no recollection of that at all . A further part of the question asked whether the Prime Minister, being a popular figure, the champion of civil liberties, the most successful Prime Minister in the history of this country, and all those things which Senator Jessop--

TALK.START.PARA: —If not the world.

—If not the world. With the Prime Minister being all those things to which Senator Jessop refers, I am asked whether the Prime Minister will intervene in this matter to give a visa to these couple of people who are coming here for some conference, the added motive being to teach the left wing a lesson , for goodness sake. Will the Prime Minister do all these things? I will ask him . I am sure that, in answer to that ludicrous question, Senator Jessop will get an answer which he deserves.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to today's editorials in the Courier-Mail and the Daily Sun? Is it correct, as stated in the Courier-Mail, that when the Queensland Government signed the Medicare agreement yesterday it did so on virtually the same terms as it was offered a month ago? Is it also correct, as stated in the Daily Sun, that Mr Bjelke-Petersen's stand against Medicare was a tactical blunder? Has Mr Bjelke-Petersen claimed that Queensland 'won' agreement for a special Commonwealth Grants Commission on its case for additional funds? If so, did not the Commonwealth state many months ago that Queensland should take its case to the Grants Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to the editorials in the Courier -Mail and the Daily Sun. I think Senator Colston drew them to my attention actually. In the Daily Sun the headline is 'Medicare row is Jo's big blunder'. It is interesting that both papers take the same line, as Senator Colston has said-they reflect the indignation felt by many Queenslanders about the thoughtless and petty game playing in which the Premier of Queensland has been indulging to the detriment of not only his own Government but all the people of Queensland. Mr Bjelke-Petersen has procrastinated to absolutely no avail over the signing of the Medicare agreement. His signature on the agreement yesterday was a signature on an agreement giving the same terms as those that the Queensland Government was offered over a month ago. Not only has he made a political blunder, he has involved to an unforgivable extent the welfare of the people of his State in his actions.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of the refusal to sign the Medicare agreement, Queenslanders were deprived of some $6m a month to upgrade the levels of patient care in the public hospital system. As a result of the Queensland Government's decision, the people of Queensland will now receive the benefits of the $6m per month Commonwealth grant that the Queensland Government had denied them by refusing to sign the agreement before. The Minister for Health advised the Health Insurance Commission--

TALK.START.PARA: —Then what is the Minister talking about? It is a lot of rubbish .
—Order!

—I really have some difficulty with the high intellectual content of Senator Walters's interjections. I understand that yesterday the Minister for Health advised the Health Insurance Commission that as a result of the signing of the Medicare agreement, the Commission would be in a position to bring down its private health insurance contribution rates and to make appropriate adjustments so that contributors received back any extra payments that they may have made while the Queensland Government refused to sign the agreement. In addition to this benefit, private insurance rates will be able to be based on a charge of $80 a day rather than the $120 a day which was the case without the payment of Commonwealth funds.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Bjelke-Peterson apparently says that he has won the case. He has signed an agreement which is exactly the same as the agreement that he has been refusing to sign for the last month. It has taken him a month to sign the agreement, and all the benefits that the Queenslanders would have received will now be received continuously. But, what is more important, the agreed reference to the Grants Commission could have been secured a month ago. It is exactly the same reference as that which the Federal Government offered back in early February. I just think it is a pity that Mr Bjelke-Peterson carries on in this way. But as the Courier-Mail said:

Now the agreement has been signed, much of this confusion should disappear. And now the federal money is flowing into Queensland hospitals, perhaps the health Minister, Mr Austin, will find that his Department can employ more nurses.

That will give the people of Queensland the services they desire. I think it is quite silly-I always have done-that the Premier of Queensland and his Health Minister should behave in this way to the detriment of patients in Queensland public hospitals and Queenslanders generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Attorney-General. I note that last Thursday, 1 March, the Attorney-General refused to accept any authority in regard to the case of Michael and Lindy Chamberlain. He said the matter was entirely the responsibility of the Northern Territory Government. In view of these statements, does the Attorney-General consider that since the Northern Territory acquired self-government the Territory has received plenary legislative and executive powers? If so, how does the Attorney-General explain the apparent contradiction between his denial of any authority of the Federal Government to interfere in the Chamberlain case, on the basis that it is a Northern Territory matter, with the Government's stated intention to interfere in another Territory matter, namely, the criminal code? Will the Attorney- General give some indication of when and in what circumstances the Federal Government will in the future seek to interfere in the Northern Territory's affairs? Will the Attorney-General outline the Government's perception of the term 'self-government'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My recollection, although I will need to check this, is that the terms of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act retain a residual capacity in the Commonwealth Government through the Governor-General in Council to override or to recommend changes to Northern Territory legislation based on the provisions of that Act. It is my recollection that that does not extend to overriding executive decisions of the Northern Territory Government, even though the case be a good one. As I said, I will have to check that, but in answer to the question my belief, at first blush, is that that is so. More importantly, one has to look at the actual merits of these competing situations. So far as the Lindy Chamberlain affair is concerned, despite its bizarre-to use Senator Button's favourite word-characteristics as a case and the popular attention it has excited--
—That is not my favourite word.

—Well, it is one of the honourable senator's favourite words. He used it a couple of times today. It is a good word-an excellent and very appropriate word. The honourable senator's use of it today reminded me how good a word it is. In circumstances of this case, despite its idiosyncratic characteristics which have made it the subject of such popular attention, it is essentially an ordinary matter to do with the administration of criminal justice by reference to familiar standards of criminal proof in the context of the familiar offence; that is, murder or manslaughter, as the case may be. There is nothing to suggest that the criminal process has been other than followed in a normal and entirely satisfactory manner through all the successive stages of appeal.

ANSWER.PARA: When, however, we are talking about the Northern Territory criminal code a very different situation confronts us. This criminal code has brand new provisions, many of them highly questionable and highly challengeable but four of which in particular raise absolutely fundamental questions about the terms on which Australia as a nation has adhered to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It also, in at least one instance, raises fundamental questions about the whole Anglo-Saxon tradition of criminal law that we have inherited and hitherto applied all around the country. There is a head-on challenge to those concepts and those principles in a number of provisions of the code which have been the subject of a quite lengthy process of communication and negotiation between the two governments.

The course of action that is proposed at the moment does not yet, I believe, justify the description 'interference' as Senator Kilgariff has employed it. We have made clear our belief that certain aspects of the code ought to be amended. The most recent communication from the Prime Minister to the Chief Minister has indicated that if no satisfactory response to our latest communication is obtained within a short period, we will recommend to the Governor-General that he in turn recommend to the Northern Territory changes to the code. That is still not interfering to the extent of applying different provisions or repealing or disallowing particular provisions of that code. That is a further step that could be contemplated at the end of the road, but all of us hope that will not be necessary.

Mr Everingham responded to that last letter of the Prime Minister, I understand a few days ago, saying that he wants to have a meeting with the Prime Minister and me to discuss this matter further. The Prime Minister has today written back to Mr Everingham, having consulted me before sending the letter, saying that he, together with the Attorney-General, would be happy to meet Mr Everingham to discuss the matters in issue. That is where the matter presently rests. I hope that meeting will take place in the near future. I hope that sooner rather than later an appreciation of the fundamental principles involved in this matter will strike Mr Everingham and that he and his Government will behave perhaps a little bit more sensitively that they have to date.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he has seen the item in today's Australian Financial Review headed 'Macphee seeks public funding for child care', in which Mr Macphee is reported as saying that the ready availability of cost effective, quality child care was:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . crucial to the ability of parents to exercise their rights as individuals to equality of opportunity.

He called on the Hawke Government to improve on what he said had been a poor performance in this area. Can the Minister set the record right with regard to this Government's performance in the child care area, particularly in light of the Fraser Government's years of principled neglect and Mr Macphee's difficulties in persuading his colleagues to such views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the article referred to by Senator Crowley but I will look at it with interest. I find it an interesting and extraordinary statement, coming from a Minister in the previous Government, especially a government that had what was euphemistically known as a year of consolidation and review in the children's services area, which meant that it did not spend any extra money in that year. This Government has had increased expenditure of $ 10m in the children's services area. I am sure that next year we will have more increased expenditure. We have directed those funds to areas of greatest need. We are reforming the system so that we can introduce a planning model for the introduction of new children's services schemes rather than the existing submission model which inevitably, as we all know, favoured those areas where more articulate, wealthy people lived.

ANSWER.PARA: We have expanded the areas in which we are willing to assist. For the first time 24-hour day care services have been funded. We are looking at innovative areas throughout the whole system of children's services. In particular, in co- operation with the New South Wales Government, we have continued and will expand a program started by the previous Government whereby the New South Wales Government provides land, either through local government or through the Land Commission. That Government has developed standardised plans for children's services and, through its Department of Housing and Construction, is developing standardised techniques for building these children's services so that the costs have come down considerably. Mr Walker, the New South Wales Minister, and I will be announcing shortly another large batch of children's services programs in these areas.

Having consulted the various groups concerned with child care in the community, we are in the process of developing a new system of subsidies for the special economic needs in the area so that the system will be more simple, so that we will direct funds more to those who need them and so that we can more efficiently and economically develop the sort of children's services program that this country needs. I do not think there is any justice in Mr Macphee's remarks. I think any comparison between our program and our attitude in this area with that of the previous Government will make it quite clear which government shows the most interest and has developed the most services.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNION OF SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS: EXIT VISAS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Following the detailed answer given to the question asked by Senator Childs regarding the possibility of exit visas from or for South Africa, could the Minister inform the Senate in similar detail what are the rules of exit visas from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; in particular, thousands of Jewish and other USSR citizens who wish to leave the USSR? As the reason given by the Government to deny entry to two South African parliamentarians was given on the grounds of the restrictive policies of the South African Government in relation to its own citizens, I take it, therefore, that since this is the new policy of the Labor Government the same restrictions in respect of visas will apply to all USSR citizens until they are free to travel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not even think that was a very good try. I have not said that the decision about the refusal of entry to the two South Africans was justified by the restrictive policies of the South African Government in these specific cases. I answered a quite specific question by Senator Childs. I certainly do not support, and I am on the record many times accordingly, the restrictive practices of the Government of the USSR, the Government of East Germany or any other Eastern bloc government that Senator Lajovic might like to quote. I said in answer to a question yesterday that the decision about the two South African members of parliament was made on the basis of those individual cases. These South African MPs were coming here under the auspices of the South African Government for propaganda purposes. Seminars were organised by the South African Government representatives here. Fares and expenses were paid for people to come to those seminars which were going to be confidential or secret.

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of the fact that Australia has signed the Gleneagles Agreement to signify that it is opposed to apartheid-all parties in Australia are supposed to be opposed to apartheid-we were not going to have the sportsmen bear the brunt of it. In this particular situation, a decision was made that the members of parliament would be refused entry. Of course, this Government and other governments have refused entry to representatives from the USSR and other countries of that type. I dare say they will again. But to suggest that the refusal of the South African Government to allow critics like Bishop Tutu and others out of the country is the sole reason for the refusal of the entry of these two people is not something I have said, the Minister of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has said or the Minister for Foreign Affairs has said.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: SECURITY BREACHES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that the Department of Foreign Affairs did not contact Mrs Van Dartel during its investigation of her allegations concerning misuse of the diplomatic bag and security breaches? In light of this, can the Minister seriously suggest that the departmental investigation was anything other than farcical?
—I am not aware of the precise circumstances of the departmental investigations in this particular matter but I will endeavour to find out and give Senator Primmer a reasoned reply.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister for Health instructed the Health Insurance Commission to issue its own receipts to patients who are claiming reimbursement from Medicare of payments to doctors? Has this been hastily arranged following a flood of complaints from Medicare staff who were illegally retaining doctors' receipts? Has the Minister publicly announced the procedure? If not, why not? What are the details? Will patients be able to receive their own receipts, which are legally theirs, from their own doctors?
—I do not know. I will find out.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In light of the recently released discussion paper on income support for young people, prepared by the Office of Youth Affairs and the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat, when can we expect some decision to be made in relation to the level of unemployment benefit paid to 16 and 17-years-olds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion paper referred to by Senator Foreman was released by Senator Ryan and me a couple of weeks ago. Its purpose was to inform people about the multiplicity of payments for young people in the community, the complexity of the system we have, and also to point out the very real difficulties we face in trying to reform the system in this area. Neither Senator Ryan nor I, however, is satisfied with a situation where some 66 per cent of young people in this country are either in the work force or unemployed and receiving inadequate benefits, whereas in comparable countries the percentage is very much lower-about 34 per cent of those aged between 15 and 19 years. We would like to see more people remaining in the education system and receiving training and preparation for life in the work force, whatever that life may be.

ANSWER.PARA: At the moment we are asking interested people to read the document and to contact us with submissions and ideas. We are looking at many options. In the meantime, of course, we will not forget the unemployed aged between 16 and 18 years. Their benefit was increased last year. Whether it will be increased this year and by how much will depend on Budget discussions which will commence shortly. The Budget is the appropriate time to make such increases. We will be able to make more radical changes to the system which, incidentally, now has 36 or 37 different payments to youth for various purposes. Any changes depend very much on how quickly Senator Ryan, I and others can develop policies in this area which are not only desirable but workable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on the basis that I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been handed a note describing an exchange at Question Time in the House of Representatives today in which the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, mounted an attack on me for allegedly suggesting on Radio 2GB this morning that there might be some connection between the bomb attack on the Family Court judge's home in the early hours of this morning and the verbal attacks on the judiciary which, most regrettably, have taken place in this chamber in recent days and, indeed, in the Parliament as a whole. It was suggested that that was a quite outrageous sentiment on my behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put it in context and explain my position. As I recall, I was awoken by Radio 2GB at about a quarter to seven this morning, having gone to bed, I add at about half past one. In a rather sleepy and befuddled condition-indeed, I think early morning interviews can count as cruelty to dumb politicians-I heard the news for the first time of the attack on the judge and I was asked to utter some appropriate responses. Of course, I expressed my shock and horror at it. Thinking aloud, really, I said that it seemed to me that the kind of attacks that had occurred in the Parliament tended to encourage the kind of community climate in which crazies would be likely to be moved to perpetrate outrages of this kind. It was an essentially innocuous sentiment and not intended to have any more weight than that. Shortly after I put down the phone it started ringing with a series of calls from other stations. It occurred to me that sentiments of that kind, while perhaps having some objective justification, were likely to be misconstrued.

Certainly I did not want to suggest, or to be taken as suggesting, that for all the other outrages the Opposition has perpetrated in recent days it would in any way lend any degree of support whatsoever to the kind of outrage that occurred in this instance. So long as there is any possibility of a misconstruction of that kind being attached to remarks of this kind, I certainly would not make them. Indeed, without revealing the secrets of the Party room, when I was asked a question in the Party room this morning as to whether the Government would make something of the possible connection between attacks of the kind that have occurred on the judiciary and the attack on the judge, I expressed in very strong terms my view that it would be quite inappropriate to do so and that we should make no statement of that kind. I believe my Party colleagues will vouch for that. I assure honourable senators that it was a quite unprompted response on my behalf. Against that background the allegations and suggestions of Mr Peacock assume their proper status. Because other people have chosen to occupy the political gutter in this country in recent days it does not mean that we on this side of the Parliament will go down there and join them.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Attorney-General to respect the role of the Parliament and to respond properly to the issues raised by the 'Age' tapes.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the personal explanation which has just been given by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is a nice example of why the Opposition has so often had cause for complaint about him. He has a tendency to speak without thinking and certainly a tendency to act without relating his actions to the principles he is so keen on espousing in this place. We bring this matter of public importance forward because we regard the issue before the Parliament as a serious one. We think it is important to remind the Parliament what it is that we face in the issue of these tapes. I take the most down-played version of what has been displayed by the tapes in quoting the opinion of Ian Temby, QC, who said on the basis of the material that it 'is not consistently salubrious'. I think most of us would regard that as a fairly extraordinary understatement. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Several of those who have spoken, if they could be identified, would be hard put to deny general involvement in activities including illegal bookmaking, race -fixing, bribery, and prostitution.
In the same opinion Mr Temby very gently referred to matters raised about the judge. Even Mr Temby said in reference to the association between the judge and the solicitor:

It places a judge in an invidious position if he has frequent dealings with any person of poor reputation. Presumably (the Judge) now realises this and will act more carefully in the future than he has done in the past. If there is doubt in this regard, it may be that he should be approached and advised as to the desirability of not further nurturing the relationship he has with (the Solicitor) if it presently remains on foot.

I suggest that that lawyer-like understatement is reflective of the best complexion that one could put on what has been exposed by these tapes. I refer to what a notable lawyer, Dr I. C. F. Spry, said in a letter to the Age last Saturday when he referred to the fact that the 'Federal judge is alleged to have engaged in questionable conduct'. In fact if one looks at the accounts which appeared in the Age newspaper one finds not merely reference to the network of illegal behaviour that is raised by these documents but also a series of allegations about a person who is described as a senior judge-allegations of a sort which I believe no ordinary Australian would regard as in any way appropriate as coming from a judge. I do not believe that in the jury of public opinion there would be any possibility that the behaviour allegedly exposed in these tapes would be regarded as acceptable on behalf of a judge.

If this set of tapes stood alone as a simple, single peak on the landscape I suppose the Opposition's concern to press this matter might be regarded as excessive. The reality is that this is just one of a depressing succession of similar revelations. We have had a succession of inquiries and we have had a succession of results. At the moment it is fashionable for Labor politicians such as the Attorney-General and Mr Wran to complain that people are saying that there is fire when there is merely smoke. I remind the Senate that in Australia we have a lot of allegations of smoke and a lot of evidence of smoke. We have had inquiries by such people as Mr Justice Street, Mr Costigan, QC, and Mr Justice Stewart. Those gentlemen have certainly exposed plenty of smoke but the record of recent years shows, I suggest, that there is plenty of fire too.

There was plenty of support from the Labor members of this place when the previous Government moved to take action against organised crime and tax evasion . Indeed their complaints were that we were not moving strongly or harshly enough. However, over recent months we have seen people such as Mr Humphreys convicted as a result of one of those smoke inquiries. We have seen Mr Farquhar committed for trial because of one of those smoke inquiries. We have seen Mr Jackson resign from his ministry because of exposure about things which conflicted with what he had said in Parliament. We have seen a senior policeman, Mr Allen, affected by those inquiries. It is short term electioneering and political nonsense on the part of the Labor Party, of Senator Evans and the Government generally to try to reduce this to some suggestion that we are dealing with smear and with matters which are not of great public moment and immediate concern.

This is not a matter which the Opposition has suddenly produced on the eve of an election. As I have said before, these matters have been produced by independent journalists in the main. From where did they get their raw material? I cannot be sure of that but I put the very firm view that the great bulk of this opinion comes to journalists because of the frustration of honest policemen who believe that inquiries are not going to be followed through to fruition. In any event there is a real problem which has to be tackled and which goes to the very substance of Australian society and Australia itself. In the instant case the clear tactic of the Attorney-General is to contain and suppress these matters instead of fearlessly pursuing them. That tactic preceded the announcement of a State election in New South Wales. Last week the Attorney- General refused to answer questions which were put to him by the Opposition. He refused to make material available. He made some admissions of fact but he was very careful about what he did. Since the election was announced he has made greater efforts. I believe that the transparency of the Attorney-General's approach is made most evident by his action late in the sitting yesterday. When the question of the adjournment of the tapes debate came up for consideration and the adjournment was moved by Senator Macklin, what did the Attorney-General do? He moved a motion that the matter be made an order of the day, not in the normal course for the next day of sitting, but for the first sitting day after 25 March 1984. It appears on the Notice Paper as an item of business for the first sitting day after 25 May 1984 because that is where the Attorney-General wanted it. He laughed at the time because, of course, his tactic was simple. He wanted to remove the debate from this place until after Mr Wran's hurried election.

The main complaint which the Opposition makes about the Attorney-General is that he has been contemptuous of the Parliament's role, although in the ultimate he admits Parliament has a key role, a role which is unique in this area. The Attorney-General now admits that it is the Parliament-not the Attorney-General, not the Solicitor-General, not some QC advising the Government, not the Prime Minister which carries the responsibility for dealing with allegations of judicial misbehaviour. Yet in the face of that admission by the Attorney-General and in the face of the admission of all of his advisers that that is true, he has consistently refused to give to the Parliament the information which he willingly provided to counsel to advise him on these matters. The counsel whose advice he sought has consistently told him that this is a matter which ultimately rests with the Parliament. That is contained in Mr Temby's opinion. On the second page of the opinion he talks about the fact that this is a matter for Parliament. I will quote him since he has been so heavily relied on by the Attorney-General. Referring to the question of the removal of a judge, he said:
That is of course a matter upon which only the Parliament could decide, if it chose to embark upon the exercise.

That, of course, is the central point which underpins the Opposition's demand for information in this matter, because this is a matter which only the Parliament can decide. Similarly, the Solicitor-General, Dr Griffith, in his opinion, makes it quite clear that it is the Parliament which has the power to decide these matters, although his opinion seems to raise the suggestion that the Parliament could be brought to book if it exercised that power in a way which some external body thought right. I note that Senator Tate shakes his head , but I note also that Dr Griffith said:
Parliament would act beyond the power if it sought to apply wider definition or criteria for misbehaviour than the recognised meaning of misbehaviour not pertaining to the office.

The reality of the situation is that which was admitted by the Attorney-General in debate yesterday. Judicial misbehaviour is a matter for the Parliament. Judicial misbehaviour and Parliament's decision on it are matters which are not justiciable. They are beyond the reach of the courts. That was an admission by the Attorney-General yesterday which sits ill with his conduct in this matter.

The revelations which face the Attorney-General are revelations on which he has taken some action. When finally the Age took the matters to him and when the Age published those matters, certainly the Attorney-General showed some greater urgency than he appeared to show when Senator Archer raised the matter weeks and weeks before that, towards the close of last year's parliamentary session. We know nothing about the inquiries which were put in train then, except that the Attorney-General says that they were continuing and had been subsumed by the new inquiries. The Attorney sent the matter off to his colleague the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr John Brown), who sent it off to the police. He subsequently sought an opinion from Mr Temby and made material available to him. He then established a task force under Mr Temby as the Special Prosecutor. He subsequently sought an opinion from Dr Griffith. The Opposition wonders why it took the Attorney so long to go to the second law officer of the Crown. He even took it upon himself to visit the judge and to talk to him about the matters which were raised in the tapes.

The Opposition is simply not satisfied with various aspects of this matter. It is certainly not satisfied with the personal performance of the Attorney. I am sure that the Attorney will respond in vigorous terms about how proper and how appropriate he has been. We say to the Attorney that he stands to be judged by the very high standards which have been set for Attorneys-General and the high standards which have been quoted in debate in this place. Indeed, I again use the words of Lord Shawcross, which I believe are as good as can be found in explaining what sort of duty lies upon Senator Evans in this matter. Lord Shawcross said, after he had been through a period of great difficulty in a matter of great political difficulty, that he had a duty:
. . . to be wholly detached, wholly independent and to accept the implications of an obligation to protect what he conceives to be the public interest whatever the political results may be.

That is the standard which is demanded of the Attorney-General. That is one of the bases on which we criticise him today and on which we have criticised him in the past. We do not think that he has shown total detachment, that independence and that desire to protect the public interest whatever the political results may be. The simplest and most recent illustration of that is his pushing back of debate until after the New South Wales election when his political colleague, Mr Wran, has to face his political masters. It would be instructive for Senator Evans to ponder upon the context of Lord Shawcross's remarks because Lord Shawcross was talking about a situation in which he had to take action which was not helpful to members of the government of which he was a part. The words of Lord Shawcross were his affirmation of his prior public duty, even in circumstances where it was to the detriment of certain of his friends and political colleagues. That is the standard we expect of the Attorney-General. We think that it is not the standard we have seen from him.

I shall touch very quickly on some of the detail as to why we think the Attorney has shown less than the sort of competence that is required in this matter, quite apart from the issue which has been so much discussed already of his refusal to give Parliament the information it needs. We have questioned publicly whether Mr Temby was the most sensible and desirable person for the Attorney to go to for an opinion. That matter has been the subject of comment outside this chamber and in debate here. The fact is that Mr Temby is the putative Director of Public Prosecutions and he has been given a task in this matter which the Attorney told us will become merged with or be carried on along with that role as the Special Prosecutor. The Attorney has conceded that the statutory duties of a Special Prosecutor and the statutory duties of a Director of Public Prosecutions are not the same and that in particular their relationship to the Attorney-General are not the same. We do not believe it is a wise thing for there to be confusion or any possibility of confusion. We also believe it would have been better had the Attorney-General gone to a lawyer without any political affiliations because that again would have avoided any question of that sort being raised. I believe Mr Temby was asked to give an opinion when he was not given all the information available to the Attorney- General. In particular, it is apparent that he was not given the aide-memoires to advise on following the discussion with the judge. In that and other particulars we believe the Attorney has not handled this matter in a competent way.

As far as the task force is concerned, the Attorney-General may well argue that the most adequate way in which to tackle the very many allegations of illegal behaviour contained in the tapes is to establish a task force. The Opposition quarrels with the fact that he has excluded any further examination of the actions of the judge, expressing himself satisfied as to that situation in a public statement with his ministerial colleague. We also question whether a task force is adequate to deal with this matter, given the limited powers of police. I am sure that any senior policeman, when asked, would say that in the sort of task which has been set the police by the Attorney-General in this matter their limited powers will make it difficult for them to get to the truth. An inquiry with the wider powers of a royal commission might have some chance of bringing the people involved to justice. The police will have an extremely difficult task indeed.

We have made clear in debate that we are not satisfied with the Griffith opinion and that we disagree with it in some respects. We have made it clear that we do not think the way in which Dr Griffith relied upon the Constitutional Convention debates is appropriate. There has been lengthy quotation from those Convention debates which I believe bears out that Opposition viewpoint. The key point which comes through from the discussion in the Convention debates is that the behaviour of judges cannot be left to the judges, because they themselves are involved. This is a matter for Parliament, and it is the Parliament alone which can settle this matter; and it is the Parliament which has been denied information by this Attorney-General. That view was borne out by a radio interview which the Attorney may not have heard because, having just got out of bed, he may have been under the shower. Professor Lane was interviewed on AM this morning and, when asked how misbehaviour is proved, he said:
