PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 February, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-By arrangement with the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party, we thought this would be the most expeditious way of discussing briefly the notice of motion I have on the Notice Paper, No. 33 on page 2923, before the debate on this Bill ensues. On 2 March I presented the following notice of motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That, pursuant to Standing Order 358, there be laid upon the Table all documents containing advice from the Commissioner of Taxation to the Treasurer concerning the desirability or otherwise of the provisions contained in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983.

In moving the motion later I quoted, with the authority of the former Treasurer, some parts of a memorandum dated February 1980 from the then Commissioner of Taxation to the then Treasurer, which, not to put too high a point on it, suggested that at that time, namely, February 1980, firstly, there were more urgent aspects of tax avoidance to be tackled and, secondly, there seemed to be no evidence that there had been massive evasion of tax through the scheme which this legislation sought to arrest. Therefore, I, with my Party and with the support of the Opposition, believed it was reasonable, if in February 1980 it was not considered by the then Commissioner of Taxation to be an urgent matter, to ask why clause 5, I think, of this Bill dates the legislation back to 1 July 1977. I think that is the crux of the matter. Therefore, I put down that notice of motion asking the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to produce that information.

Today I received from Senator Walsh, who represents the Treasurer in this chamber, a letter from the Treasurer to him dated 5 March 1984 in which the Treasurer predictably said, for what in the past were regarded as good reasons by the Liberal Party when it was in government, that he could not comply with that request of the Senate and will not do so because of the long-established convention that these matters, namely, the advice of a public servant to a Minister, should not be disclosed. The Treasurer then gave some reasons why the Government felt impelled to insert clause 5 in the legislation. For the sake of the record I seek leave to have this letter from the Treasurer to Senator Walsh dated 5 March incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Treasurer PARLIAMENT HOUSE CANBERRA 2600 5 March 1984
Senator the Hon. Peter Walsh
Minister for Resources and Energy
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
My dear Senator

I refer to our discussion on Friday afternoon concerning the motion moved by Senator Chipp calling for the tabling of documents containing advice to the Government by the Commissioner of Taxation as to the need for the measures contained in clause 5 of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983.

The Government is not prepared to table all documents received from the Commissioner of Taxation tendering advice to it in relation to this matter. These include Cabinet and other materials which are properly kept confidential.

The former Treasurer asserted during the debate in the House of Representatives that he had received advice from the Commissioner of Taxation just before the change of Government to the effect that Part IVA had wiped out all blatant, artificial and contrived tax avoidance schemes and that therefore these particular superannuation practices could not be in that category. On this premise Mr Howard claimed that the practices could not therefore meet the criteria necessary to satisfy the Government's retrospectivity policy confirmed by the Minister for Finance in his statement of 28 April 1983.

By long established convention the Commissioner of Taxation cannot inform me what particular advice he tendered to the former Government, but I have no reason to doubt that the former Treasurer quoted accurately from written advice he received from the Commissioner. Of course, the particular context in which the Commissioner made his remarks may place a different emphasis on them than did the former Treasurer in his speech. I think, however, that what the Commissioner had in mind when giving his advice to the former Government just prior to the election was those schemes which were known as ''paper schemes'', that is those which were quite artificial and, in reality, devoid of any fiscal effect other than the attempted avoidance of tax.

If that, as I suspect, was the case, then there is nothing inconsistent with the Commissioner's advice to me and to the former Government in relation to these particular superannuation tax avoidance schemes. they are not of the extremely artificial variety, nor are they of a kind at which Part IVA was directed.

That does not, however, mean that they are not blatant or contrived or even artificial in terms of the application of the Government's policy on retrospective tax amendments. In the Government's view they are clearly in that category of schemes which we intended would be covered by Mr Dawkins' statement on the Government's retrospectivity policy. Mr Dawkins' statement specifically referred to schemes which might not be caught by Part IVA. Not only are they of a most blatant kind, but they contain elements of fraud against employees, many of whom stood to benefit from many years' membership of a superannuation scheme which has been afforded substantial taxation benefits. The Government's retrospectivity policy was clearly not intended to operate only against purely paper schemes.

The nature of the schemes in question was set out in my press statement of 14 November 1983 (copy attached). During the debate on the Bill in the House of Representatives, I drew attention to a judgment by Mr Justice Wootten which vividly described the type of scheme involved. One of the employees in that case was sacked on a Friday, re-employed as a casual on the following Monday and, as a result, denied a superannuation entitlement of over $53,000. If Opposition Senators do not regard schemes of that kind as blatant or contrived, then that is a view I cannot share.

The decision to propose that the measures in clause 5 should have a retrospective operation from 1 July 1977 was taken by the Government after full consideration of the nature of the schemes, and after noting the essentially fraudulent nature of the activities involved, both in relation to employees of the business concerned and the revenue. The overall monetary effect on the revenue was not the critical consideration, given the unsavoury nature of the practices involved.

I am confident that our decision to propose that the legislation be made retrospective was the correct one in this case and the Government proposes to press ahead with the Bill in its present form in the Senate.
Yours sincerely P. J. KEATING

I have under my own hand circulated to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle a copy of that letter, albeit just before the dinner suspension. I hope that I did not offend any confidentiality, but Senator Walsh did not indicate that any confidentiality attached to the letter. So the Opposition is armed at least with the reasons given by the Treasurer.

I can understand the Treasurer's hesitation in not tabling documents received from the Commissioner because they include Cabinet material properly kept confidential. However, in this instance I believe the Treasurer could well have made an exception and would have been wiser had he done so. The Government is attempting to introduce this legislation retrospectively to 1977. Even those in this chamber who favour retrospective legislation-and they do not include me, Senator Haines or Senator Macklin-would realise that it sets dangerous precedents and undermines the rule of law. Therefore, they must be prepared to make out a very good case as to why legislation should be made retrospective. The Government's case for retrospectivity in this instance has been brought into question by the former Treasurer's statement in the House of Representatives on 29 February that the advice that he received from the Commissioner of Taxation in 1980 indicated that this type of tax avoidance was not a major problem then and that an attempt to remedy the situation might create many problems for the large number of funds that are completely genuine and, therefore, for the many small businesses that operate them.

As I said in my speech the other morning, we have suffered an economic downturn in this country. Let us consider what would happen with a small business that had genuinely started a superannuation fund for its 20 employees, including the directors and, through the business having gone badly because of the recession 14 of them, say, had been sacked, for very good legal and proper reasons, and then finally the business had gone into liquidation and the superannuation fund had to be wound up. As I understand it, according to the definition in this legislation, the residual beneficiaries of that fund would have received 'an excessive benefit'. Because they have received a benefit, this legislation will give the Commissioner of Taxation power to deem that they have received an excessive benefit and to tax them in the year in which they receive that benefit or the year in which it accrues to them. He would deem that to be income and that would be assessed, in many cases, at the marginal rate of over 60c in the dollar.

Today we received firm positive assurances from a senior officer of the Australian Taxation Officer, which gave me a great deal of satisfaction, that this would not be the Commissioner's intent, and that the Commissioner will be zealous in applying this Act only in those cases which he regards as barefaced, where an obvious attempt was made way back in 1977, or since then, to avoid taxation by a totally artificial scheme. I respect and believe everything that that officer said to Senator Jack Evans, Senator Macklin and myself in Senator Walsh's office. We just express the view, the five Australian Democrats, that while we honour that sort of assurance and respect it from a respected taxation officer, we would prefer it to be written into the legislation to give that sort of safeguard to the genuine cases.

The officer went on to say that the aggrieved taxpayer can well appeal against the use of the Commissioner's discretion, either through a board of review or, sometimes, a court. But he acknowledged when I pointed it out that, under our taxation law, at that point of time the taxpayer has the onus on him to prove that he was innocent of any misdoing. I have already quoted in this chamber from the document which the Commissioner of Taxation furnished to the then Treasurer. It seemed to me to require a similar response from the Treasurer showing us why the Commissioner had now brought further evidence that the proposed section 26 AFA ought to be made retrospective to 1 July 1977. The Treasurer has not given me, therefore, an adequate response to evidence that fundamentally undermines his case for retrospectivity in this instance.

I have some sympathy with what the officer said to us today: That a great number of these schemes were entered into by employers as far back as 1977 but at the time the then Commissioner of Taxation gave the then Treasurer, Mr Howard , the memorandum the mischief had not surfaced-namely, the employers acted on the advice of those despicable creatures who live on the fringe of the accountancy and legal professions and who make a living out of advising people how to go into these schemes. Senator Hill may laugh, but I hope that he joins me, as a distinguished lawyer himself, in condemning those despicable creatures who live on the fringe of his profession, the legal profession, and of the accountancy profession, who make a fortune out of the tax avoidance industry. They were advising their clients to go into these schemes in 1977, but to make them look fair dinkum until about 1982-83.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that is very rare.
—What is rare?
—It was very rare that an accountant or a lawyer advised anyone to go into a scheme of that nature and make it look real.

—Senator Hill must be talking with his tongue in his cheek in saying that. As a former member of the accountancy profession, I often cringe with shame at some of the advice that I hear is given to taxpayers by qualified accountants in relation to schemes which, when I practised accountancy, I would not have touched with a 40-foot pole.
—What I am saying is that it has to be put in its right perspective . They are very rare exceptions, advising people to enter into totally artificial schemes.

—I admire the stand that Senator Hill takes against retrospectivity. I am still against retrospectivity. I do not want that to be misunderstood. However, if Senator Hill were to have a discussion with the admirable taxation officer with whom we spoke today, I am sure that he would be persuaded that many wilful schemes were entered into on the advice of crooked lawyers and crooked accountants in 1977 which did not become manifest as rorts until 1982-83. That is the excuse, apparently, that the present Government uses to date this legislation back to 1977. It is a plausible excuse. If one believes in the principle of retrospectivity, it is a reasonable excuse. I will not have a bar of the principle of retrospectivity at any price. Therefore, notwithstanding how good the reason is, I reject it.

SPEECH.PARA: To complete this matter, at about five minutes to eight-I say this with no criticism of Senator Walsh-Senator Walsh handed me a letter addressed to the Treasurer, dated 6 March, from the Acting Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, pertinent to the point. I have not even had time to make a copy to give to my friend and colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. It would have been extraordinarily valuable had this letter been circulated to the Opposition before the debate proceeded.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be done shortly.

—Perhaps Senator Walsh will make the arrangements. I do not know whether the Government can delay this debate for a quarter of an hour so that Opposition senators can look at the letter before they speak. It contains some pertinent facts. The Commissioner states that the practices are 'brazen and barefaced' and involve 'abuses of the tax law', and so on-with which the Australian Democrats agree. I think that Liberal senators agree about that. We agree with this legislation. The only part of the legislation with which we disagree is its retrospective aspect.
—What is meant by 'abuses of the tax law'?
—The Commissioner does not go on-
—He uses the word 'artificial'?
—Yes, and I am persuaded that this is an artificial practice which ought to be stamped out, and therefore I agree with the thrust of what the Government is trying to do.
—Not in all cases.

—Before Senator Watson came into the chamber, I had been at pains to cover those aspects about which he now says 'not in all cases', and I absolutely agree with him. We were assured today by a senior officer of the Taxation Office that the genuine cases will not be touched by this legislation. In response to that, I then said that I would prefer to see those safeguards written into the bill rather than being left to the Commissioner's discretion. So Senator Watson and I are at one.
—Why cannot the assessment simply be overcome by section 172?

—I am informed that the assessments of those years-say, between 1977 and last year-cannot be reopened because the payments by the employer into the fund constituted at that stage genuine premiums on behalf of employees. The only assessment that can be reopened, as I understand the information given today, is that which was made in the year in which the rort was discovered or deemed to be discovered by the Commissioner. That is the reason given to me. It is a pity that this valuable advice from the Commissioner will not be available to people such as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, Senator Hill and Senator Watson before the debate ensues.
—It will be soon.
—I thank the honourable senator. With the authority of Senator Walsh, I seek leave to have this letter also incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
6 March 1984 The Treasurer,Parliament House,Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 5) 1983

You have asked that I provide you with further advice as to the nature of the practices against which clause 5 of the Bill is directed and, in particular, whether they can be categorised as blatant and contrived.
In terms of general usage, as I understand it, they can-as I now explain- be so described.

We have a situation where a superannuation fund has been set up ostensibly for the benefit of the employees of a particular firm. The fund is governed by a trust deed the terms of which will have been looked at by the Taxation Office with a view to ensuring its compliance with the law, section 23F in particular. Tax-deductible amounts will have been contributed by the employer for the employees, both those who are proprietors and those at arm's length. The contributions will have been invested and income from the investments accumulated tax-free.

What then happens is that steps are taken with a view to moneys in the fund being re-directed, solely to those employees who are proprietors of the business . This re-direction involves the premature dismissal of the arm's length employees and is either in breach of the trust deed or involves the payment of benefits far in excess of permissible levels.

That kind of thing involves clear elements of raids against the revenue and also against the unsuspecting ordinary employees concerned. It may well have been that there was this intention from the outset, but if that is so the intention is one that is kept masked from ordinary employees and the Taxation Office.

The practices seem to me to be brazen and bare faced and involve abuses of the tax law which, in the superannuation area, contains generous concessions intended for the benefit of the employees on whose behalf contributions are supposed to have been made. The arrangements are ingeniously planned to give the appearance of bona fide superannuation arrangements.

In providing this advice, I am aware of the comments made by the former Treasurer in the course of debate in the House of Representatives. As you would appreciate, there is difficulty in my providing you with comments on or explanations of advice given to the former Government by the Commissioner on the matter. It is, I hope, enough for me to say that, when the advice that Mr Howard has referred to is read in its context, it is not at variance with the advice now provided.
As to the revenue effect of the proposed measures, identified cases of the kind to which clause 5 applies, involve revenue of some $15m.
T. P. BOUCHER Acting Commissioner of Taxation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its indulgence. I have no standing in this situation. I am speaking by leave and with the indulgence of the Senate. I do not know what Senator Walsh's view on this matter is but I think that this information is so crucial to an intelligent debate that the debate ought to be delayed for at least a quarter of an hour. If the Government has any other business perhaps it could be called on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not want to make a second reading speech on this matter but there are a number of matters which I think I ought to try to explain and clarify. The first item before the Senate relative to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983, as I understand it, is the motion that Senator Chipp moved the other day.
—No, that is not before the Senate.
—It is not before the Senate?
—Not at the moment.

—I would like to make a couple of comments about that, anyway. As Senator Chipp has explained, he sought to obtain all or at least a substantial part of the memoranda and advice which the Commissioner of Taxation has provided to the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) on this question. The Treasurer has refused to make that information available except in a very limited form-I will come to that later-first, on the grounds that there is no precedent, with one exception to which I will return later. Indeed, there is an objection in principle to advice of this nature being tabled in the Parliament because if that became a standard practice, the Commissioner of Taxation and a number of other public servants would be very seriously constrained in the advice they could give to a Minister or to a government. Secondly, I am advised that the first communication that the present Treasurer received from the Commissioner on this matter was in the form of a draft Cabinet submission. I do not think anyone would suggest that draft Cabinet submissions, under the Freedom of Information Act or anything else, ought as a matter of practice to be made available to the Parliament. Thirdly, in the memoranda that the Treasurer has received from the Commissioner of Taxation a number of matters were normally canvassed-perhaps five or six separate issues-one of which may be this issue. Fourthly, those same memoranda frequently contained discussion or suggestions-speculation perhaps-as to tax legislation which the Government may consider contemplating not only in respect of these cherry picker schemes which are the subject of a portion of the Bill but also in respect of other matters. The letter written by the Treasurer to Senator Jack Evans on 1 March which Senator Chipp has had incorporated in Hansard explained-
—No.
—The honourable senator has had the letter of 1 March incorporated , has he not?
—No, only the letter from the Treasurer to you of 5 March.

—I am sorry; I have that wrong. A letter was written to Senator Evans on 1 March-copies of it, I think, have been provided to the Opposition-in which the Treasurer explained the basic reason why legislation is required to deal with these cherry picker schemes. That basic reason is that superannuation funds are established and contributions are made to them, usually exclusively by employers, but those funds can continue for a number of years. The employers claim deductions from their taxable income for the employer contribution and the earnings of the funds, as is the case with all superannuation funds, are exempt from taxation in the hands of the fund. Under the existing law, only in the last year of a fund, that is, when it is improperly wound up or terminated in a way that seeks to advantage the manipulators of the fund or the owners or managers of the company and not the employees for whom it was ostensibly established, may the Commissioner disallow the deductions claimed by the employer, who is the ultimate beneficiary in most cases of these types of artificial schemes of the taxation exemption for the employer contribution. The existing law does permit the Commissioner to go back and deny exemptions in all of the previous years for which exemptions or deductions from the employer's taxable income has already been allowed. I note-I think this is important, even though it is perhaps more of a second reading debate matter-that the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) in the House of Representatives on 29 February quoted from a letter or a memorandum sent to him just before the last Federal election by the Commissioner of Taxation. He quoted the Commissioner as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, as a result of your new Part IVA all the blatant artificial and contrived schemes are a thing of the past.

An amendment was also moved by the Opposition in the House of Representatives, and notice of the same amendment has been given here, to provide that the date from which this provision becomes operative, stated in the Bill as 1 July 1977, be altered to 7 December 1983. In other words, the Opposition has argued by way of that amendment that there should be no retrospective application of this law and has simultaneously argued in quoting the Commissioner that 'all blatant artificial and contrived schemes are a thing of the past' following the proclamation of Part IVA. It seems to me that it follows that the Opposition has declared total opposition to legislation with retrospective application-even though I note in passing that that inhibition was not apparent among the same people in 1982-and also argues that the legislation presently before us is superfluous following the proclamation of Part IVA in 1982. The only logical outcome of those two propositions-I hope I have interpreted them correctly; I certainly have not intentionally misinterpreted them-is that the Opposition ought to be opposing the entire section of the Bill and not just seeking to alter the date on which it becomes relevant.

Senator Chipp commented on the letter from the Commissioner to the former Treasurer written in February 1980. I would like to add a couple of comments. First, that letter from which he quoted, I think on Thursday of last week, was written in early 1980 when the Commissioner's top priority from the documents which had been tabled in 1982 by the former Treasurer, among other sources, was clearly to terminate the bottom of the harbour schemes. At that time the Commissioner gave a relatively low priority to the schemes at which the relevant section of the Bill before us is aimed. Since that period, however-this is additional--

TALK.START.PARA: —He also said most of them appeared to be genuine.

—Yes, I was coming to that. A great deal more evidence has come to the Commissioner's notice since that time. A particular and very blatant case- the Kelly v. Raymor case upon which Mr Justice Wootten delivered a verdict on 18 November 1982, a copy of which has been circulated to all honourable senators- showed how blatant some of these schemes were. There have been some Federal police investigations and the Commissioner or the Australian Taxation Office also believe that as a result of the proposals and later policy of the present Government to alter the tax arrangements for lump sum superannuation payments, a number of those schemes have been wound up. In other words, the importance of these schemes, as a result of later evidence coming to light, is much greater than the Commissioner had believed at the time he wrote that letter to the former Treasurer in February 1980. I should like to refer to one paragraph at the end of the letter dated 6 March 1984, which I think Senator Chipp has incorporated, where the Taxation Commissioner, writing to the Treasurer, says:

SPEECH.PARA: In providing this advice, I am aware of the comments made by the former Treasurer in the course of debate in the House of Representatives. As you would appreciate, there is difficulty in my providing you with comments on or explanations of advice given to the former Government by the Commissioner on the matter.
I interpolate that I am sure we are all aware of that problem. The Commissioner continues:
It is, I hope, enough for me to say that, when the advice that Mr Howard has referred to is read in its context, it is not at variance with the advice now provided.
The advice now provided in that same letter says, among other things, in a description of the type of funds at which this section of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983 is aimed:

We have a situation where a superannuation fund has been set up ostensibly for the benefit of the employees of a particular firm. The fund is governed by a trust deed the terms of which will have been looked at by the Taxation Office with a view to ensuring its compliance with the law, section 23F in particular. Tax-deductible amounts will have been contributed by the employer for the employees, both those who are proprietors and those at arm's length. The contributions will have been invested and income from the investments accumulated tax-free.

The letter goes on to state that what then happens is that the employees who are ostensibly the beneficiaries of the fund are in one way or another deprived of their entitlement. The entire proceeds are ultimately distributed to the effective managers of the fund, usually the owners of the company.

I should like also to refer to the Treasurer's 5 March letter which Senator Chipp incorporated. This is a letter from the Treasurer to me and which I had previously made available to the Australian Democrats and the Opposition. The Treasurer says:

I think, however, that what the Commissioner had in mind when giving his advice to the former Government just prior to the election was those schemes which were known as 'paper schemes', that is, those which were quite artificial and, in reality, devoid of any fiscal effect other than the attempted avoidance of tax.

Schemes of that type are virtually one-day round-robin schemes in which cheques are handed around and claims are made for deductions from taxable income for contributions to a fund and the money is paid out on the same day. They are a quite different type of scheme from those at which the legislation presently before the Senate is aimed. The schemes at which this legislation is aimed have in all cases been in existence for a number of years. They have operated more or less in a normal way, with the exception that the employees rarely made any contribution. The employees were frequently ignorant of the existence of the scheme. Contributions were accumulated over a number of years and those contributions earned interest and compounded. The schemes only became clearly fraudulent at the time they were wound up or at the time that various devices were employed to defraud the employees, for whom the schemes were ostensibly established, from their entitlements. The Treasurer goes on in the 5 March letter:
If that, as I suspect, was the case, then there is nothing inconsistent with the Commissioner's advice to me and to the former Government in relation to these-
I interpolate, 'these' being those schemes which are covered by this Bill-
particular superannuation tax avoidance schemes. They are not of the extremely artificial variety, nor are they of a kind at which Part IVA was directed.

I am afraid that this is a very complex issue. If I have explained it imperfectly I apologise. It is difficult, even after one has spent some time studying it. In summary, the legislation presently before the Senate is essential in order to recover the tax deductions improperly claimed on schemes which were wound up between 1 November 1977 and May 1981, when Part IVA of the principal Act was proclaimed. It is also probably necessary to recover tax on deductions improperly claimed in that post-May 1981 period for the reasons that Treasurer gave in that 5 March letter to which I have just referred. That is, the schemes at which this legislation is aimed are not of the kind at which Part IVA was directed. It may be arguable that Part IVA could recover the tax improperly evaded through the manipulation of these schemes following proclamation of Part IVA, but I am advised that there is no certainty that that could be done.

Finally, Senator Chipp asked a couple of questions towards the end of his speech about the operative date for the legislation, that is, 1 July 1977, and the reason for it. The reason is that the first instance known to the Taxation Commissioner, not of the existence of funds of this type but of the disgorgement of benefits from those funds in an improper way, was in August 1977.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by 'an improper way'?

—A way in which the employees of the company, for whose benefit ostensibly the fund was established, are deprived of their entitlements in that fund and the contributions on which exemption from taxable income has already been claimed and on which income earned within the fund has been tax exempt, are ultimately directed or harvested, if you like. I understand that the colloquial term is 'cherry-picked'.
—Cherry what?
—The cherries are ultimately picked by the managers of the fund, who are usually the owners of the company, the employers.
—That is the problem that ought to be solved, is it not?
—That is what the legislation will do.
—No, it does not do that. The employee gets nothing and the Taxation Office get everything.

—In most cases the employee was not aware of the existence of the fund. These are artificial, contrived, blatant schemes, the intent of which was at all times to defraud the Taxation Commissioner of revenue. Senator Harradine was not in the chamber yesterday so he may not have had an opportunity to read Mr Justice Wootten's judgment, which I circulated to most honourable senators initially last week and finally yesterday. Under this legislation the employer is required to pay tax on the contributions to the fund which were allowed on the presumption that the employee would benefit from the fund. Since the employee does not benefit from the fund the rationale for the original tax exemption disappears. It is that fraudulent intent by the managers of these funds which this legislation sets out to correct.
—I will be moving an amendment later.

—Well I dare say the honourable senator will move any amendment which he thinks will protect tax evaders; he has habitually done so in this place. Finally, the estimate of revenue which is contained in the last sentence of the letter which Senator Chipp has tabled is at this stage $15m. That is a minimum figure and the ultimate figure could-although this is getting into the realm of speculation-be a great deal higher than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This statement follows the statement made by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, and the statement made by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh. I am disappointed that the motion by Senator Chipp for all of the information to be supplied from the Australian Taxation Office has not been successful. I, like Senator Chipp, do not wish to impugn public servants because they are dedicated officers, but what we want to see is the actual advice that is given and the detailed information on which this advice has been formed. We do not have that. We have some examples --
—One example.

—We have one example. We do not have other examples. I reiterate that what the Government is doing here is virtually saying: 'Well, there have been these schemes. They have been devised improperly'. That is why I asked Senator Walsh what he meant by the word 'improperly'. He said that ' improper' in that context meant that employees who were supposed to be the beneficiaries of these schemes have been deprived of the benefits and those benefits have been cherry-picked by the managers of the schemes. The answer of the Government to that problem is: Tax the cherry-pickers. Well, where does that leave the employees? Where does that leave the workers who have been deprived of the benefits of these particular superannuation fund schemes? It is no satisfaction at all for them to see the Taxation Office get a bit of extra money .

SPEECH.PARA: I would have liked to have had, and expected to have had, the benefit of further information which would be available to the Commissioner of Taxation and which would now be available to the Senate if Senator Chipp's motion were adopted. Failing that information I am proposing an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill, most certainly not for the purposes about which Senator Walsh has made comment, but to ensure that those who have been deprived of the benefits are, in some way, compensated for the loss of those benefits. There are various ways of doing this. Senator Walsh said that the employees in many cases did not know of the existence of the superannuation fund. That is very true. I know that for a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every trustee should know. There is a requirement that the Commissioner will approve, that every trustee must be informed.
—Only if he contributes.

—No, it is not only if one contributes. The Taxation Office will inform one that in the appropriate forms there must be, as I understand it, a provision which refers to the fact that the beneficiaries, the employees covered, have been advised of the existence of the schemes. As I understand it- the Minister can correct me if I am wrong-that is the situation.
—They are all supposed to be advised about all the dangerous chemicals and those sorts of things, but you know they are not.
—The point I am making is that here is a situation where we have had the managers of the scheme acting-I do not know whether fraudulently is the word--
— Improperly.

—Certainly acting improperly and the workers who are supposed to be the beneficiaries getting nothing. They are still going to get nothing if we pass this legislation. Therefore, I will now have to retire and consider what will be the appropriate amendment to the second reading motion so as to ensure that the workers get something, and not just the Taxation Office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) does a number of things with regard to taxation proposals . I do not wish to make any long comment on some of those issues. Such things as the withdrawal of the investment allowance where property is used in tax exempt activities, leverage leasing about which I would like to have time to say something, special concessions for Australian trading ships, deductions for investment in qualifying Australian films and exemption of payments of special benefits to victims of major disasters are, in many cases, tax issues that have been announced either in whole or in part by the former Government or have been the subject of Budget announcements or other announcements by Ministers of the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three matters to which I would like to address some attention. One of the matters is that which we have been discussing since 8 o'clock this evening, that is, the tax avoidance practices in relation to employees' superannuation funds. Our interest in this matter started with the debate in the House of Representatives in which the shadow Treasurer moved an amendment on behalf of the Opposition relating to the retrospectivity of the proposal before us. The matter has been developed further in the Senate by Senator Chipp's motion requiring information from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) with regard to the advice that he had received from the Commissioner of Taxation. It will be recalled that the shadow Treasurer in the other place made reference to his advice from the Commissioner in 1980 and then later in 1983 with regard to matters of tax avoidance or legislation that may have been required by the then Government. With regard to employees' superannuation funds, about which we have been talking , there are some queries in my mind arising from what has been said this evening . I have now the benefit of the letter from the Treasurer to Senator Walsh of 5 March. The advice that he has-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, did you not have that before?
— I had the letter of--
—The letter of 5 March. I though you had it yesterday.

—Yes. I said I have the benefit of that letter. I have it here. The letter that I had earlier was the one dated 2 March which Senator Walsh addressed to me and which gave the judgment of Justice Wootten. Senator Chipp made available to me this evening the letter to Senator Walsh from the Treasurer dated 5 March. We now have the further letter from the Commissioner to the Treasurer dated 6 March. It was made available this evening.
—I am sorry, I meant to give you the letter of 5 March.

— I did not have that one earlier. However, I have been able to read what was in that letter. The thing that has confused many of us is the lack of information as to the need for the proposals that are now before us. If we look at the existing tax Act, with regard to section 23F funds we find that what is now before us to counter tax avoidance seems to lack some continuity. If we look at the tests that are made by the Commissioner to determine whether funds are properly section 23F funds, we must wonder why the Commissioner could not simply deal with the tax avoidance that we are now discussing under the Act as it exists. Proposals and tests are applied as to whether the funds are genuinely set up for the benefit of the employees and the trust deeds are such that if at any time the payments are not in accord with them the Commissioner may act. What we want to know precisely is why it is thought that the Taxation Commissioner could not operate under section 23F with regard to abuses that are now referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine made statements with regard to the employees not gaining benefit. I can understand that a tax amendment Bill may not be the place in which such benefits would be protected. But it is known that the industrial commissions in the States can order the payment of entitlements to employees under some of the legislation which now exists, particularly the New South Wales Employment Protection Act of 1982. Those matters would relate to some of the things that were referred to by Senator Harradine earlier tonight. But in the case of a proper section 23F fund I would want to have absolutely precise information as to why the Commissioner feels that he needs to reach back to 1977 in order to deal with a payment improperly made out of that fund at any particular time, and why he would need to go back to 1977 when a fund fails to meet the test at any point of time. The Commissioner may determine that that fund is not an exempt section 23F fund for the income year.

In circumstances where the Commissioner contends that blatant tax avoidance has occurred, or that fraud upon the revenue and unsuspecting employees has taken place, it is open to the Commissioner to contend that the fund was not a section 23F superannuation fund and had never been such. As such, all contributions to the fund which had been deducted from the employer could be disallowed. Senator Walsh said earlier tonight that that would not be the case; that he could only refer to the last income year in which the abuse of the fund had been detected. I would wonder why the Commissioner would not look at some of his powers to disallow deductions which had been granted to the employer in cases where the discretion of the Commissioner, exercised at the time, is considered erroneous. We would want to know why the power contained in section 170 (8) could not be used at any time that there had been a payment in abuse of the trust deed of a particular fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; what power is that?

— I refer to his power under section 170 (8). In cases in which deductions had been erroneously granted by him, he should be able to use that power instead of requiring a new power under the provisions that are before us. After all, the determination of whether it is a section 23F fund is subject to very precise tests by the Commissioner. The Commissioner has the power to look at those funds to determine whether they are superannuation funds set up for the benefit of employees. That would include investigating the work and non-working directors and their dependants. A fund would not qualify for exemption unless it satisfies the tests which are prescribed in section 23F (2). In particular, the fund must be indefinitely continuing and must be exclusively established and maintained to provide benefits for the employees and/or for the payment of death benefits to their dependants. That would come under the sole purpose test of section 23F (2) (a). Further benefits being provided by the fund for any employee must be reasonable, having regard to a number of factors considered relevant by the Commissioner. That is provided under section 23F (2) (i). Unless the benefits being provided are considered reasonable, the employees ' fund will not qualify for exemption under section 23F.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the failure of any of the tests that the Commissioner may use at any time to determine the proper use of section 23F funds, it is of interest to me to hear further argument on why the Commissioner needs these retrospective powers to deal with a particular case, only one of which has been referred to us , the judgment that was given by Justice Wootten. As I understand it, that case was subsequently settled. There was a family argument within a company and it quite blatantly contravened section 23F. As I understand it, it was settled. I regard this judgment as being no substantiation of the requirment to go back to 1 July 1977 to prove the new powers which the Commissioner now seeks.

Senator Walsh read some parts of the advice that was given to the former Treasurer with regard to Part IVA and blatant and contrived schemes. I am interested in this because one minute these schemes are being called blatant and at another it is said that they could not be caught under Part IVA. It would be one thing if Senator Walsh was talking about the period from 1 November 1977 to 1981 when Part IVA was included in the Income Tax Assessment Act. But we are talking about bringing in an amendment in 1984 that reaches back to 1977 without , as Senator Harradine, Senator Chipp and I would contend, having any idea of the numbers of funds which will now become evident as not meeting the requirements under section 23F. I will leave that matter and perhaps return to it later. I believe that some of my colleagues want to refer to it also. There will be a debate on it during the Committee stage because of the amendment which the Opposition proposes to move.

I turn now to another matter which is referred to in the amendment Bill before us. This relates to short term life assurance policies. The Government, in its own words, is extending the proposal announced by the former Treasurer in August 1982 to subject to tax bonuses from life assurance policies under four years duration to those which are under a duration of 10 years. The advice that I have is that the life assurance industry did not have strong objections to the proposals of the former Treasurer when he was relating these matters to policies of under four years duration. However, there are strong objections from the life assurance industry now to the proposal of the Government to extend this period to 10 years.

This places normal insurance business at a strong disadvantage where it is heavily investment oriented as against other investment mediums, such as unit trusts and property trusts. A unit holder in a trust who could receive profits on realisation of his units after 12 months without paying tax on those profits, provided he is not classified as a trader, would be in a position of substantial advantage in comparison with someone who had a life policy of something under 10 years duration. The life assurance industry provided a table to the Opposition-I know the table was also made available to the Government-showing the extra benefit to a unit trust or property trust investor on the same investment of, for example, $40,000 compared with a typical single premium life policy over terms under 10 years with the difference representing in effect the loss of taxable revenue.

The Treasurer contends that the rebate provision will ensure that policy holders will not be doubly taxed on capital gains. This is clearly incorrect as many policy holders will pay double capital gains tax because, firstly, they might be in the 46 per cent or 60 per cent marginal tax bracket and the rebate is 30 per cent. They could be normally in the 30 per cent tax bracket but because of the aggregation of capital gains tax in a single year they become 46 per cent or 60 per cent taxpayers in the year of cashing in their policy. Therefore it is not just a simple little extension from four years to 10 years of a proposal that was mentioned by the former Government. It is an extension which makes it much more likely that a taxpayer who is paying at the rate of 30 per cent will suffer a double capital gains tax.

I say quite briefly that changing from four years to 10 years alters the underlying nature of the measure previously announced because of the practical effect of the change. I am told that no consultation took place with the industry as a whole on that change. The Treasurer justified this by alleging that life office management would have made the discussions public or would otherwise have made use of privileged information, thus resulting in the loss of some tax because people would have rushed to place money in policies of four years before the new arrangement was introduced. The industry is somewhat concerned about that sort of lack of trust because at the time of the discussions concerning the four-year proposal with the former Government confidentiality was fully maintained. The industry has challenged the present Treasurer to provide any evidence to the contrary.

The Treasurer, in a letter to the industry, said that the legislation is directed at essentially short term investments dressed up as policies of life assurance to exploit taxation incentives intended for long term life assurance and that there was a need to take decisive action to put an end to this form of tax avoidance. It is probably defensible to say that in respect of policies for two years, three years or four years, but if it is a policy of up to 10 years it would seem to be drawing a very harsh distinction compared with other forms of investment. I would think that in the case of the 10-year policy and the disadvantage that will now arise from this proposal there will be a continuing belief that it is unfair competition as far as other methods of investment are concerned. It certainly is something that could have been discussed with the industry and may have resulted in something that was not as incompatible with what it would have believed could have been achieved in comparison with other forms of investment.

The other matter to which I wish to refer is the matter of leverage leasing. Again there is some concern with regard to this matter. I know that this is a measure that was announced in 1981 and 1982 by the former Treasurer to curb the use of certain leverage leasing and similar arrangements. I think we are all aware that the use by tax exempt organisations of leverage leasing as a means of financing their business or their capital requirements had become something that was eroding the revenue that could properly be expected to be received by the Commonwealth Government. With the introduction of the leverage leasing legislation we have the general effect of the denial of all tax deductions in circumstances where the use of a leveraged arrangement will benefit non- residents using property outside Australia or owners of existing plant or tax exempt bodies. The investment allowance and the accelerated depreciation write- off are intended to provide tax incentives to private enterprise investing in new plant in Australia. In such circumstances we believe the use of leverage leasing to be admissible in that it is providing an encouragement for private enterprise to invest in new plant.

We are also in agreement that the investment allowance and accelerated depreciation benefits should not be allowable in other circumstances. We are concerned, however, about the scope of the legislation. We are particularly concerned that its effects could be far more far-reaching than the intent of either the former Treasurer or even the present Minister. The legislation is extremely penal in that it denies all deductions to the owner of property in certain circumstances. At the same time it does not remove from assessment any income which the owner derives in respect of the use of the relevant goods. In other words, the owner pays tax on the income and receives no deductions in respect of the particular business. Accordingly, it is essential that this legislation apply only where it is in the absolute interests of public policy that it does apply. I think we all recognise that we have a mixed economy in this country and that there are cases where industry and government work together. In these circumstances it is only to be expected that there will be a substantial interchange of goods and services between the private and public sectors. It is in this area that the Opposition is particularly concerned about the far-reaching effects of the legislation.

In particular, we are concerned about instances where, for example, private enterprise supplies goods or services to an exempt body to the precise specification of the exempt body. Let us take as an example a railway authority which requires private enterprise to manufacture and supply a product. Private enterprise might purchase the required manufacturing plant to the specification of the authority. The manufacture might then be supervised by the authority. It would seem in this circumstance that the legislation will apply. Similar concerns relate to proposed section 51AD4 (a) (ii), which deals with plant which is leased. We have no difficulty with the general thrust of the legislation, but we do believe that in certain areas it goes too far. For instance, under sub- section (10) of that provision basically all deductions are denied to a taxpayer at any time that this legislation applies. The Commissioner has in most circumstances no discretionary powers. Just a partial use of something-a matter of a day, a week or a month in which leased equipment could be used-would then deprive that person of any tax benefit.

I am told that a lot of industries would be affected by this legislation because of the far-reaching consequences of it and the neglect to take into account partial use in giving benefits. Plant hire to public authorities would be caught under section 51AD (4) (a) (ii). It could apply to contract services to public authorities-for example, truck operators employed by a State mine. Privately-owned plant could be used in construction work by public authorities- for example, in the construction of buildings, houses, dams and road works. Private plant could be controlled by State enterprises-for example, a mine rail car on State railways. We could have private plant being supervised by a public authority-for example, the specification and supervision of private enterprise manufacturing plant. We could have privately-owned plants supplying services to private enterprise-for example, privately-owned electricity, sewerage treatment, water treatment and harbour facilities. If the relevant services form part of a State reticulation system, effective control may be present. It is the words ' effective control' within the amendment that is of concern. The industries include privately-owned plants supplying services to both private enterprise and public authorities-for example, privately-owned electricity plant, sewerage treatment plant, water treatment plant and harbour facilities. If the relevant services form part of a State reticulation system again, effective control may be deemed to be present. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a list of the sections of the Act under which it is believed that these industries could be affected by the proposals that are before us.

TALK.START.PARA: — I thank the Senate. The three matters to which I wish to refer particularly are leverage leasing, about which I have just spoken, the proposals with regard to superannuation and the short term life policies. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal with two aspects of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983. The first, and more important so far as I am concerned, is that relating to section 23F, superannuation funds. I also want to deal briefly with the new tax consequences on what has been described as short term life policies up to 10 years. I think I will be briefer than I intended because I understand significant amendments will be put before us tonight which I have not had the opportunity to see but which I gather will substantially change the provisions of this Bill. I return to the matter I mentioned that is of particular concern to me, that is, the new tax that will be imposed tonight and which will be retrospective to 1977. The other day I spoke briefly on this matter before the debate on the Bill was adjourned because it appeared from my perusal that it was an unnecessary piece of legislation, that there were adequate powers in the taxation Acts to ensure that section 23F funds are not used for the purpose of tax avoidance. I take it from the second reading speech of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) that that is the purpose of this legislation. Also it follows that to make it retrospective to 1977 is totally without justification and should be rejected out of hand.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, raised a number of questions that have been put by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the other place principally seeking information on why the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation appeared to have changed his mind since 1980 when Mr Howard, then Treasurer, was given advice that legislation in relation to alleged abuses of these funds was unnecessary. That is a question that particularly interested me. I do not believe from what I have heard tonight-I have not seen anything before tonight from the Minister-that there is evidence that circumstances have substantially changed in the meantime.

My fear was that this legislation was being based upon one case which the Minister, I concede, has distributed to honourable senators, Kelly v. Raymor ( Illawarra) Pty Ltd. It is a New South Wales case which, upon anyone's perusal, presented a most unsatisfactory state of affairs. It is a very big step to take one bad case and produce retrospective legislation to 1977. Therefore the other day I asked how many cases were involved. Regrettably as yet I have not had an answer to that question. I am also interested to know how much tax has been lost by these alleged abuses. Again, unfortunately, I do not have any information on that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteen million dollars.

—I do not think that answers the question that I asked. I will explain. Tonight Senator Chipp tabled, with the Minister's consent, a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation dated 6 March which states in its last paragraph that the identified cases-the kind to which clause 5, the clause about which I am speaking, applies-involve revenue of some $15m. However, I do not know how that $15m is calculated. Is that $15m, which will now be taxed, revenue that can be raised under new clause 5 if it is brought into law? That is very different from the tax that would have been lost under the law as it exists at the moment. For example, I do not know whether it takes into account the possibility of the Commissioner reopening assessments in relation to contributions that have been made by employers. It appears to me from the extreme case of Kelly that clearly assessments can be reopened and disallowed. Am I to presume that all these figures are taken into account-the new tax that is imposed by clause 5; the tax that can additionally be gained by the reopening of assessments? If it is a case of fraud-'fraud' is a word stressed in the Minister's speech-the Commissioner can go back without time limit. If all this is correct, the figure of $15m becomes rather meaningless. It is not informative for my purposes and I suspect not particularly informative for the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage I do not know how widespread this abuse is. I have a suspicion that the contrary is the case, that it is a very rare abuse. Apparently today Senator Chipp had discussions with an officer of the Department of the Treasury and he has been convinced that at least some cases are involved apart from this very unsatisfactory one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner had a briefing last night from the same officer.
—I understand Senator Messner had a briefing also. No doubt that will be helpful to Senator Messner but it is not particularly helpful to me.
—I understood that he was speaking for the Opposition.

—The shadow Minister has already spoken on this matter, and I do not think she had a briefing. These are questions that I raised two days ago in this place and I thought they should be answered and could be answered in the meantime. I regret that they have not. I also asked whether it could be explained why Part IVA could not be used in relation to the abuses of the type described by the Minister that have taken place since 1981. I know that the Minister briefly touched on this matter tonight, but I think it is fair to say that he has not explained to the Senate why it cannot be used. If I recall correctly he said there could be some practical difficulties. There are often difficulties in enforcing provisions of taxation Acts. Surely not every case in which we encounter difficulties demands further legislation particularly of this nature. Surely the Senate has the right to see that enforcement under existing provisions is not possible. That is why I asked the other day: Why not Part IVA? I have not had an answer to that. I asked why the Deputy Commissioner could not use other provisions he has under the Act. In an interjection to Senator Chipp tonight I mentioned section 170 of the Act. I cannot see, and it has not yet been explained to me, why assessments cannot be reopened. As I said, if they are of the nature of fraud they can be reopened at any time. —It will be explained.

—I am pleased that it will be. I also asked: Why the critical date of 1 July 1977? That has not yet been satisfactorily explained. I think that when one considers that problem one has to take into account the advice that was given to the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, in 1980.
