SPEECH.PARA: I have read the letter from the Commissioner of Taxation, which I have only just received tonight and which purports to detail the types of abuse involved. I am somewhat surprised by the wording of that letter. References to raids against the revenue and matters of that nature appear to me to be more suited to a different type of correspondence. In relation to the type of abuse he outlines in that letter-we know of one case which has occurred; the premature dismissal of employees simply for the purpose of gaining a benefit under a superannuation fund, particularly in the circumstances that are stated in the Bill-the Commissioner said:
It may well have been that there was this intention from the outset.

This, I would concede, is a highly unsavoury affair and certainly nothing that anyone on this side of the chamber would condone. We say that, short of evidence being put before us, that is a very rare situation. We have been told of only one such case. Furthermore, we suggest to the chamber that adequate powers are available to the Commissioner under existing laws to do something about it. I mentioned the other day, for example, the fraud provisions of the Crimes Act. If we are talking about a scheme that has been set up with the intention from the outset of defrauding either the revenue or employees, I cannot understand why action cannot be taken under the provisions of the Commonwealth Crimes Act. I asked that question the other day and have not yet received an answer. I hope that the Minister will be able to deal with it later in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did you ask?

—I asked Senator Walsh, but he had left the chamber. At the end of Senator Chipp's speech the other day I used the opportunity to list in this chamber a number of questions. I think, in fact, that the Minister was attempting to answer some of my questions to Senator Chipp tonight, but the answers are not in full and, I regret, are not as yet to my satisfaction.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it might be of some benefit if I give some background on the structure and purpose of section 23F, which relates to superannuation funds, for those in the Senate who have not had a lot of experience with taxation Acts or superannuation funds. Section 23F does, of course, relate to one form of employee fund. Its purpose is to provide for superannuation payments for the benefit of employees upon their retirement. Such payments are made into the fund by an employer. The employer is obliged by the provisions of the Act to do this on an annual basis. Payments may also be paid into the fund by the employees concerned. The incentive for the employer to make contributions is that they are tax deductible. The incentive for the employee to make payments is that in certain circumstances they may be rebatable. Provided the fund complies with the rules as to reasonableness contained in section 23F and the rules as to the type of investment, the income from that fund is exempt.

I think that section 23F can reasonably be described as a measure that gives considerable legitimate taxation advantage. The rationale obviously is that it is worth while to provide incentives to enable employees to retire in reasonable comfort without being a drain on the state. So the state contributes at the time of the employee's employment through forgone revenue rather than theoretically after his retirement through increased provision of pensions and benefits. Those of a socialist persuasion may not like the rationale for schemes of this nature, but to me, and I think to those on this side of the chamber, it is sound and wise. Obviously there must be provisions in the Act to ensure that the tax- exempt quality of funds is not abused, that funds are not used simply as taxation avoidance measures, and that they do not take from the state an unreasonable proportion of revenue. So the rules of fair play which have been contained in the Act since the start of this scheme in 1964 have been varied from time to time. I think they were varied most substantially in 1982.

The rules of fair play, if I might call them that, are that the fund must be continuing indefinitely. It must be exclusively established and maintained to provide retirement benefits for employees and/or for the payment of death benefits to their dependants. The right to receive benefits must be fully secured and forfeited benefits must be applied to the benefit of other members of the fund. The benefits to any member of the fund must be reasonable, having regard to such matters as salary, period of service, and matters of that nature. The Commissioner has developed a scale of reasonable benefits. Other provisions are included to ensure an arm's length relationship between the employer and the fund. Although the fund may be a qualifying fund, exemption, as I mentioned, is conditional upon compliance with a particular rule of investment which is commonly referred to as the 30:20 public securities investment rule.

So the first test is whether the fund is a qualifying fund. If any of these tests of reasonableness is not complied with in any year it ceases to be a qualifying fund. The consequences of that are that the contribution may not be allowed as a taxation deduction and the income of the fund may be duly taxed. Therefore, if in any year it becomes a fund that allows an excess benefit to an employee there are severe taxation consequences. That, I think, is a question which those on this side of the chamber cannot understand and which requires an answer. In the years going back to 1977, why have the funds not ceased to be qualifying funds, which gives the Commissioner all the powers he needs both to disallow the contributions that have been made and to tax the earnings of the fund? Unless there is an answer to that-I cannot see it and I see my learned colleague Senator Watson nodding his head-this legislation simply is unnecessary .

To continue my brief summary as to how funds operate, it is not surprising also that the principal of the business, if the business is a company, can also be an employee for the purposes of such funds and take benefits. It is supposed to be a fund for retirement and, therefore, under the deed it certainly may be the situation that if somebody retires early, that which has been placed in the fund for his benefit can go back into the fund for the benefit of those who remain, until retirement. The benefit in effect goes to the other employees, who may include the person I referred to as the principal. Often if a person who has been an employee has been dismissed for impropriety one will find under the terms of such funds that his benefit is forfeited. Rarely in my experience, if a person is dismissed because of economic circumstances or for some reason that does not relate to impropriety on his part, does he lose a benefit.

However, with the loss of some employees it becomes obvious that the benefit to those who remain may become excessive under the rules. That is usually dealt with by most deeds. Certainly all deeds that I have ever come across have provided for an excessive benefit fund which runs in conjunction with the normal section 23F fund in order that anything which becomes excess can be siphoned off and taxed as it should be taxed under the Act. Every prudent trustee or employer who is setting up such a fund obviously wants to draw his trust deed in such terms because he does not want to risk the losses to the fund if it becomes an excessive benefits fund. When I say 'losses' I mean the taxation consequences that I mentioned earlier. No mention has been made so far in the Minister's comments of that usual type of fund. As far as I am concerned, that covers the vast majority of funds of this type.

I do not doubt that on very rare occasions there is abuse. In fact I now know that there is abuse because I have read the one case that the Minister forwarded to us tonight. Unfortunately the answer of this Government is to take to the very rare abuse with a big stick and to affect detrimentally the interests of those who are innocent, not purely the interests of those who have acted in what we might loosely call a fraudulent fashion. It is clear that the Government found at least this one case of dismissal for the purpose of gaining a benefit for the employer. As I have indicated, that is clearly a highly unsatisfactory business. But as I said to Senator Chipp, that must be put into perspective and without further and better information from the Minister I retain the view that that would be a very rare occurrence. Instead of dealing with it under existing laws-and, as I indicated, I believe there are adequate powers for that purpose- this Government has decided to label all those who have gained an excessive benefit in quite honourable circumstances, a number of which I will mention in a moment, as being involved in practices 'involving clear elements of fraud', and it quite unnecessarily imposes upon them a new tax. It obliges them in effect to pay what amounts to a massive penalty, no matter what their bona fides. It does not purport to tax the excessive benefit. It purports to tax the whole of the payment out.

Faced with somebody who back in 1977 gained a considerable excessive benefit, quite innocently because a number of employees retired from a fund that might have been in existence for 20 years or because his salary was reduced over the last few years as a result of poor economic circumstances so that his benefit, which had been largely earned in previous years became excessive, what does this Government do? It does not attempt to tax that excessive benefit in some way. Instead, it imposes a new obligation upon the total payment he received from that fund and adds it on to his income for that one year in question, so that he probably pays at the highest of the marginal rates. To me that is quite disgraceful. If there is an explanation for it, we are waiting to hear it. That is why I asked questions the other day, and I have not yet had a satisfactory explanation.

It is true, I concede, that under this Bill a person in such circumstances can say to the Commissioner: 'Look, my circumstances are such that you should exercise your discretion in my favour'. That provision is included in this Bill, but I suggest to the Senate that it is not included in satisfactory terms. There are in the Bill no real guidelines as to what the Commissioner is to take into account in deciding to exercise that discretion in the taxpayer's favour. Basically the Commissioner can take into account whatever he considers to be relevant. I ask the Minister what that means. I hope he might tell us in due course what are these relevant factors that the Commissioner of Taxation can take into account. That is not in my opinion good tax law. It is not the type of tax law that this Senate should be passing tonight. It is casting the net unreasonably widely. It is putting an unreasonable onus on innocent taxpayers to persuade the Commissioner to exercise a discretion in their favour. As was said the other day, once it is shown that the Commissioner has complied with the form of his obligations, it is practically impossible, on appeal, to have that changed. So, inadequate protection for the taxpayer is contained in that provision. It gives the taxpayer and the Commissioner insufficient guidance as to the basis upon which the discretion should be exercised.

In concluding, might I make a few other points. I mentioned that it is not simply a tax upon the excess benefit; it is a tax upon the whole of the benefit received which, if received as a lump sum, at the moment incurs only 5 per cent tax. So, it is a massive new tax. I do not think it can be described in any other terms. It is a disincentive to proper, fair and reasonable section 23F employee schemes being set up, and that will not be in the best interests of employees in this country. The 1982 guidelines have tightened up the obligations considerably, and I have heard it said by many that the standards are now sufficiently tough that there can be no possible justification for further legislation from 1982. As I said, I believe the few cases of fraud or impropriety before that date can be otherwise dealt with. Retrospective action, as has been mentioned tonight, will not assist any employee who has been harmed by those few cases of impropriety. The person who has actually been harmed, under this legislation gets no benefit whatsoever. I think the Senate should bear that in mind. If it is said that the purpose of the legislation is to dissuade those who are of a mind to commit fraud, the provisions of the Crimes Act and other provisions which deal with fraud, specifically Part IVA of the Act , will be much more effective in dissuading that type of unsatisfactory action. I am concerned about genuine employers who should not be classified with fraudulent cases and who will be wrongly caught within this Government's net. That is totally unsatisfactory.

The proposed legislation will seek to recover a tax that was not legally payable and the payment of which has not been illegally evaded. As I said, now that the stricter guidelines are in force, it is totally unnecessary. I have mentioned section 170. I do not know why the Commissioner of Taxation is not out there reopening these assessments. I do not know why the Commissioner did not act in relation to funds that failed to comply with the guidelines years ago, so that definitely even this Government would appreciate that this provision was unnecessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —The old section 260.

—As Senator Messner says correctly, there was the old section 260 of the Act, before we had the Part IVA. Why was action not taken under that section? Failure in the past is not a justification for bringing before the Senate legislation of this type. Now auditors' certificates are necessary, and they include an obligation to show that the fund is being conducted in accordance with its constituent documents. Why has that not been mentioned to the Senate tonight? All in all, it is clear that the existing law is adequate to handle the few cases of fraud that apparently exist. This is a new, massive and unfair tax. There is no justification for it now and there is certainly no justification for it being backdated to 1977.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983, I wish to deal not with the general matters about which my colleagues have spoken tonight but with one of the many different provisions in the Bill which provide some reforms of the tax law. The provision to which I wish to refer is the provision made in section 3 in respect to special benefits for disaster victims. Honourable senators will have no trouble in recollecting that early last year saw a disastrous period of bushfires in Victoria and South Australia. There was enormous loss of life and loss of property, and there was a great deal of hardship. Many people in those States are suffering from that hardship to this time, such as people who lost their properties and have had great difficulty in having them replaced, and the people who lost relatives. During that holocaust and after it, a number of people made provision and made gifts to others. The generosity for which Australian people are noted came to the fore. Many people wanted to give some assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, those people have been somewhat blighted in their sense of national duty by the way in which the Commissioner of Taxation has operated in the treatment of the gifts that they made. This has been a matter of considerable discussion in the Parliament, but it is not a matter that is covered in the Bill. The Bill provides a special benefit for disaster victims. As the second reading speech says:

After the disastrous bushfires and floods . . . the Prime Minister announced that the income tax law would be amended to exempt from tax the first two weeks' payment of social security special benefit to the victims of those and any similar future disasters.

That was a generous little help, but a lot more should have been done. This Bill is very defective because, although it presented the opportunity to do so, it does not clear up a defect which has been brought very clearly to the Government 's attention over the last year.

Perhaps I can give a particular example of the position in which people who desired to be generous to the victims of bushfires found themselves when they made their donations in goods, in kind rather than in money. They found themselves treated by the Commissioner of Taxation in a completely different way . I should like to read from a letter from one of my constituents who wrote about this matter in July. He said:

The Commissioner of Taxation has decided to interpret the Tax Act so as to require donors of farm produce and stock to charitable appeals to pay tax on the value of such gifts-a tax which would not be paid if these were sold and the proceeds of sale handed to the charities.

Take the case of two farmers who each donate 1 tonne of potatoes to the Salvation Army. One sells the potatoes and hands the proceeds to the Salvation Army while the other ships the potatoes to the charity for its direct use in providing meals to the needy. Both farmers have made the same sacrifice of their property at the farm gate but one must pay tax on the value of his gift and the other pays no tax. It is self-evident that this is:
(1) Illogical to the point of utter absurdity;
(2) Unjust and contrary to the fundamental policy of tax legislation which requires impartial treatment, that is, equal taxes on persons in like circumstances.

People produce these goods and, as part of their produce, they pay tax on them, but they are actually giving the goods to the same charitable cause. Many people discovered this anomaly after they had given the gift.

The same writer, in a later letter and referring to the same sort of example, said that these factors could be cited in regard to the different farmers: First , they have made the same sacrifice of their property at the farm gate; secondly , both have claimed as a tax deduction their expenses incurred in producing the potatoes; thirdly, both are required to include the value of the gift as income, one as an actual sale and the other as a notional sale; and fourthly, only one, the farmer who sells the potatoes and hands the cheque to the Salvation Army, can claim the deduction. I should have thought that this being produced and shown to the Commissioner of Taxation, it would long since have produced a remedy, particularly as we live in a country which is prone to disaster and in which such things will happen quite often. One should not in any way discourage the desire of the people of Australia to give generously.
This matter was raised in the House of Representatives by Mr Bruce Lloyd on 21 April 1983. He said this to the Government:

The first point I want to put to the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) is that one of the forms of tremendous generosity that were provided during the fires was donations in kind by other farmers in areas already drought stricken. One of those forms of donation was the provision of fodder. Fodder was needed more than money to keep livestock alive in southern Victoria in the days immediately following the fires. Because of the greatest drought in our history there was already a shortage of fodder. However, those donations were not tax deductible. I appeal to the Minister to consider that situation because that was a donation far more generous than money. Money would have been useless in the circumstances . I understand there is still the problem of what happens to the advances made to people as fire relief and whether that is tax deductible. However, the main point I want to concentrate the Government's attention on is whether it is possible to do something about donations in kind, particularly when they are given with such generosity.

Of course, he did not get any satisfaction from that. In addition, Senator Harradine, on 25 May 1983, asked a question about bushfire relief donations as tax deductions. He wanted to know whether the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) were aware of the different attitudes being taken by the Australian Taxation Office in relation to donations of cash as distinct from donations in kind for the victims of the Victorian and South Australian bushfires. He pointed out the effect that this would have on gifts. In reply to the question, Senator Walsh said that he was not aware of what distinctions, if any, the Taxation Office was drawing between donations of cash and donations in kind. He said that he would seek a definitive answer from the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that?

—That was on 25 May 1983. We have almost reached the anniversary of when the complaint was made directly to you. Following that, I had correspondence with the Treasurer. I wrote to him on 28 July 1983 making the same complaint. I have had acknowledgments and I have been told that the matter is being considered by the Treasurer and that in due course some answer will be given. But I have received no definitive response.

SPEECH.PARA: I wrote again on 28 November 1983 pointing out that I had received further representations and further approaches. I pointed out then that Senator Don Chipp had a private members Bill to remove this serious anomaly. He brought it before the Parliament in this chamber on 24 August 1983. That Bill has not yet come on for debate. In November I asked the Government, because I was anxious to know, what was happening with this Bill and whether appropriate action would be taken by the Government to rectify the law to allow more people to make donations of produce and stock to those adversely affected by national disasters without being punished for their generosity and trouble. I have had no reply whatsoever to that letter. That is a not untypical reaction by this Government to correspondence in which one makes serious complaints.

Here we have legislation that would have been the obvious vehicle in which to incorporate a sensible amendment to remove this anomaly, an amendment which would give the people who wish to act generously in cases of dire need in Australia the opportunity to do so. It is a shame that the Government has not taken the opportunity in this Bill to do it. I regret that the private members Bill has not yet come on for debate. I hope that Senator Chipp proceeds with it. It seems to me that it is important that this Parliament do justice to the people of this country whose warmth of heart and generosity of spirit have been let down badly by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983 introduces a number of amendments to Australian tax law which are categorised under seven headings-withdrawral of investment allowance where property is used in tax exempt activities; leverage leasing and similar arrangements; special concessions for Australian trading ships; bonuses and other amounts received in respect of certain short term life assurance policies; deductions for investment in qualifying Australian films; exemption of payments of special benefit to victims of major disasters; and-this is the part which has incited the most comment in this chamber this evening-tax avoidance practices in relation to employee superannuation funds. All of these amendments, of course, are supported. Some are controversial and some are not. Some were mentioned by the former Government. Naturally, I support all of the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that in tonight's debate the Opposition has been deliberately obtuse. It has not been prepared to come to grips with exactly what is before the Senate in that part of the legislation referred to as covering the cherry picker scheme . I want to concentrate on that last group of amendments. I think it is quite reasonable that the Government should proceed in this area. The cherry picker scheme is a most outrageous and reprehensible tax avoidance mechanism. It is referred to in a letter received today from the Acting Commissioner of Taxation as 'blatant and contrived'. Later in the letter the Acting Commissioner stated:
The practices seem to me to be brazen and bare faced and involve abuses of the tax law which, in the superannuation area, contains generous concessions intended for the benefit of the employees . . .

I do not think anyone in this chamber would in any sense wish to defend the type of scheme known as the cherry picker scheme. It perverts the real purpose of superannuation by the creation of sham funds and it manipulates and victimises workers at the point of termination of their employment and in terms of their benefit entitlement. It avoids taxes properly due and, in doing so, deprives the revenue of a considerable amount of money to which it would otherwise be entitled. The Acting Commissioner of Taxation in his letter of 6 March has indicated the amount to be of the order of $15m.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a bare minimum.

—At a bare minimum. Of course, that means that ordinary taxpayers are treated as suckers by the perpetrators of these schemes. Ordinary taxpayers pay more because people in this country are prepared to resort to such schemes in order to avoid their proper tax liability.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, I do not think anyone in this chamber would argue that such schemes are reprehensible, but it has been argued tonight that such schemes are not widespread. It has been taken on the bases of that assertion, which I hope to demonstrate later by resort to some documentation, that therefore we ought not to move in this area as we have proposed to move. I suggest that, even if the schemes were not widespread, that would be no argument for not moving to stamp out reprehensible practices of this nature. But, of course, it is not true to say that they are not widespread; they are. They are anecdotally well known by anyone associated with the broad range of business activities, in particular proprietary companies in the small business area and people who have been employed by those companies. It is my regret that the scheme is known by the somewhat flamboyant and colourful title of the cherry picker scheme, because something as distasteful and tawdry as this type of manipulation ought not to have such an attractive title.

I think it is essential to put on the record briefly and, I hope, succinctly the nature of these schemes. Essentially, the features of a classic cherry picker operation is that a bogus or not genuine superannuation scheme is established. Usually it is established in a proprietary company, but that is not necessarily the case. However, the companies are usually small businesses. From my experience and from reports that I have from reliable sources, the people who establish such schemes are those who flirt with or are constantly involved in all other forms of tax avoidance and evasion. It seems that once the mind sets upon methods of tax avoidance and tax evasion the cherry picker scheme comes into the imagination and, unfortunately for these types of companies, is later put into practice. The principals who establish these schemes cite themselves as employers and usually pay the maximum superannuation payment into the fund on their own behalf and on behalf of the genuine employees of the company.

The workers in a classic cherry picker scheme have at best only a vague idea of its existence. Often the scheme is concealed from them so that they are not aware of it and thus cannot front up later and claim what they regard as their entitlement. To my knowledge, where the scheme is only vaguely known there is obfuscation and deliberately misleading information is given in order to put workers off the scent, to confuse them or to intimidate them about inquiring further as to the existence of the scheme. That, of course, brings forth the whole set of reprehensible employer-employee relationships. The key aspect of the cherry picker scheme is that if the employees knew of such a scheme and were able to claim their entitlements the scheme as it was designed would not operate . It cannot operate effectively where workers become beneficiaries of the scheme . I wish to return to that point later because some play has been made about that aspect in earlier debate in this chamber.

Classically, in the cherry picker scheme the principal lends his funds back to the company involved, usually at a very low interest rate, for the benefit of the founders of the scheme. Of course, it does not return a rate on investment to the scheme that would maintain its benefits if it were a genuine scheme. The provision is always that the superannuation payment is payable to fund members upon retirement. That provision is usually so constructed as to provide that in other circumstances the trustees of the scheme, who are of course the perpetrators, are in a situation of exercising discretion as to whether payment should be made other than when workers retire. Classically, they always exercise that discretion so as to avoid making payment. The other classic aspect of such a scheme is that a company frequently keeps a list such as that described in the case of Kelly v. Raymor (Illawarra) Pty Ltd by Kelly's counsel as a death list of workers who are approaching retirement and who are duped into retiring earlier so that they do not qualify under the provisions or who are sacked or retrenched before retirement. Alternatively in a cherry picker scheme the company, but not the superannuation scheme, may be transmitted to another company. Therefore the shell company folds and pays out the remaining benefit to the directors who are cited as employees. The end purpose of the whole operation is that the company owners who list themselves as employees become sole beneficiaries to the fund of the scheme and deprive the taxation authorities of revenue. Taxes are avoided by profits being diverted into the scheme. Once excess benefits are paid out and the fund is wound up no money is left to pay any other tax liability and the proprietors, as beneficiaries of the scheme, are often classically in a situation where they pay only the 5 per cent tax on termination.

As I have said, I think the bones and structure of the type of scheme we are talking about-this practice that I believe can be demonstrated as being much wider spread in the community than the Opposition will allow in the debate in this chamber tonight-should be placed before the Senate. As has been referred to by other senators, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), representing the Treasurer, has been kind enough to have circulated to us a decision by Mr Justice Wootten of the New South Wales Supreme Court in the case of Kelly v. Raymor (Illawarra) Pty Ltd. I refer those who wish to pursue the argument that these schemes are not widespread, that this is somehow an oddity of a case, to page 598 of the findings of His Honour Mr Justice Wootten. His Honour Mr Justice Wootten is referring to the fact that the litigant in this case, Mr Paul Kelly, called a superannuation consultant in order to adduce evidence from an expert witness as to the type of superannuation schemes that operate. Because of the context in which His Honour Mr Justice Wootten has quoted the matter-as an approving quotation-one must agree that His Honour accepts this as a reasonable statement of fact from an expert. He states:

A superannuation consultant called by the plaintiff, in the course of his evidence, said that from his experience he would classify superannuation funds into two categories, genuine superannuation funds and tax avoidance superannuation funds. He said that the most extreme category of tax avoidance funds would have the following characteristics.
He goes on to cite the typical characteristics of a cherry picker scheme and concludes:
In the ultimate example the benefits on resignation are never paid and few retirement benefits are paid, and the fund simply rolls on as a fund of money.
There can be no doubt that the Raymor superannuation fund was of this extreme tax avoidance category.

I conclude the quotation at that point and simply state for those who want to labour the argument that this is an oddity of a case, a rare example not typical of the type of thing that in fact happens, that we have in the Kelly and Raymor case expert evidence that establishes that there are other schemes and that this is a well known fact in terms of superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who won the case, Senator?

—If the honourable senator asks that question he should also know that the case was withdrawn by agreement. But the judge goes on to describe what can only be the moral turpitude of the type of people who operated the scheme and he took certain actions to bring it to the attention of the authorities. The honourable senator asks the question: 'Who won the case?' Essentially, no one won. Therefore, this legislation is necessary in order to make sure that the type of fraudulent activities that were engaged in here are not continued. As I have said, I believe that anyone who moves in the normal commercial world with his or her eyes open will be aware of the existence of these schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: From the point of view of putting another piece of information on the record, I am indebted to my colleague in the House of Representatives the honourable member for Newcastle, Mr Allan Morris. Mr Morris has brought to my attention a scheme which has all the classic definitions of a cherry picker scheme. It is operated by a company that a constituent of Mr Morris, a Mr Hadley, has complained about. Mr Morris and Mr Hadley have given me permission to quote from their description of the scheme to establish that, in this debate, we are not merely talking about a one-off case, Kelly v. Raymor. I wish to quote from a letter-Mr Morris has authorised me to do so-from him to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It describes the scheme to establish the bona fides of my statement. Mr Morris states:
I write concerning the operation by a company known as Carnaby Sales Pty Ltd . . . a superannuation/ Pension Fund.

I have been approached by a previous employee of the Company, who advises me that he discovered that monies from the Company were being paid into this fund, purportedly on his account. He was never formally advised of this, nor, he claims, were other employees.

I have been led to believe that significant sums of money were placed in this Fund, tax free, employees were dismissed, etc. without ever being advised of the Fund's existence, and the Principals of the Company have closed the Fund and received all monies accrued.
I understand the device is called 'cherry picking'--

I think we can labour the point that these things do not occur because we do not want to recognise that they do occur. My point is: I do not believe that argument can be put in all seriousness if we look at the case of Kelly and Raymor, if we read that decision of the judge, if we move in the commercial world with our eyes open and if we take account of the type of example that Mr Allan Morris, the honourable member for Newcastle, has presented.

I think the issue to which we should pay some attention is that millions of dollars are lost to the Taxation Office each year. Honest taxpayers are taxed more heavily as a result. We cannot be in a position of defending the tax avoidance industry. We find in the Kelly and Raymor case several very pithy quotations. But since the question was asked earlier in the debate in this chamber: 'What about the workers involved; what about their fate?', I draw the attention of honourable senators to page 597 of the document which has been circulated by the Minister. From lines 15 to 45 four cases are set out in which workers lost amounts of $50,000, $48,000, $53,639 and $40,000 to which they were entitled. All the circumstances are set out there. Had they known of their entitlement and had they been in the position to pursue a claim-a matter that His Honour Mr Justice Wootten makes it clear they were confused about or at the very least misled about and, in some cases, deliberately not informed of-they would have had an entitlement. But the point is this: This scheme operates so as to deny that information because it is not a scheme for the benefit of the workers at all; it is a scheme to avoid taxation. The whole purpose of the scheme is not to confer a benefit but to accrue an advantage to the perpetrators of the scheme.

I do not argue that any honourable senator in the debate in this House would support such a scheme. But I believe it is essential that, if we are clear on the question of not supporting it, we should be clear on what steps are to be taken to prevent it. In order to do that, in terms of tax law, the fundamental principle that has to be looked at-a principle that I have mentioned in previous debates on all the tax Bills of a controversial nature that have come before this chamber-is that there is no incentive for tax avoidance or tax evasion if there is a clear understanding in the mind of all would-be perpetrators of such avoidance and evasion that the Government, upon discovering deliberate avoidance and evasion, is prepared to legislate retrospectively to stamp out that avoidance and evasion. If they know that a government can do that, tax avoidance becomes a back number. The unfortunate aspect of the previous debates on tax avoidance measures has been that the Opposition, some Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine have not been prepared to confront that principle squarely and , as a consequence, tax avoiders have escaped their obligations. I think it is about time we confronted that principle and moved to put the tax avoidance- evasion industry to flight by enacting at least this legislation and, since the Government has foreshadowed further bottom of the harbour Bills those when they come before the chamber.

A matter that has been raised in earlier discussions is I think worthy of a particular comment from me. It has been asked: 'What about the workers who lose their benefits'? Essentially and fundamentally, although it is trite in this context to argue it, it also ought to be mentioned that the only way of protecting workers in the long run is the enactment of a national superannuation scheme. Workers who are the victims of cherry-picking schemes are typically in small enterprises that are not unionised and, therefore, have no industrial protection and are exploited by employers in those circumstances. That is cause for genuine outrage, but a tax Bill is not a way in which that outrage can be remedied because a cherry-picking scheme becomes illegal only when it has been wound up and the benefits have been taken. Prior to that point it is, from all outward appearance, a genuinely operating superannuation scheme. It may be that aspects of superannuation are not previously reported, deliberately delayed or avoided, but nonetheless it appears as a genuine scheme. The problem is that we cannot prove in advance that it is intended to be illegal. If we could, we could do something about it, but we cannot.

The surest way of preventing these sorts of schemes is the preparedness to tax them as this Bill contemplates, because if they are then taxed properly there is no advantage in establishing a false scheme. If there is no advantage in so doing, those schemes will not be established and workers will be able to obtain genuine superannuation. The whole purpose of this type of practice is not to confer a benefit but to reap an advantage. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983. This Bill contains many provisions and covers a wide range of topics. It adds, in some cases we feel quite unnecessarily, to the already voluminous nature of the Income Tax Assessment Act , which now contains over 1100 pages. For that reason I will concern myself with only a few of the amendments which have been proposed by this Bill. Although not necessarily in order of importance, they include bonuses and other amounts which are received in respect of certain short term life assurance policies, covered in clauses 6 and 25, and tax avoidance practices in relation to employees superannuation funds covered in clause 5.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the Bill gives effect to some of the decisions which were taken by the previous Government, the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government. Some of these changes, such as changes to leverage leasing, are generally welcome. However, we vocally and earnestly condemn two principal areas-the changes in relation to employee superannuation funds, and the retrospective provisions which attach to those sorts of funds under this legislation. The previous Treasurer, John Howard, was attacked because of his intention to proceed on leverage leasing tax avoidance arrangements by none other than the Premier of New South Wales, the Honourable Neville Wran. As he said at the time, it would affect a financing arrangement with a New South Wales power station. Yet today we do not hear that same criticism coming from that same Premier when a similar matter is introduced by a Federal Labor Government. However, I think I can detect that it is not quite the leverage leasing arrangements that John Howard introduced. As Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle mentioned earlier in the evening, it is foreseen by certain private contractors who are doing business with certain statutory bodies that, the income of those bodies being exempt, they could be in difficulty under this legislation.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) and the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in the early days of the Hawke Government said that the retrospective legislation would be used only in limited circumstances and only for the schemes of a blatant, artificial and contrived nature. I might not have summarised their words completely, but certainly that was the notion that was given to Australian taxpayers at large. It certainly appears from this legislation and from earlier retrospective legislation introduced into this House that, in the words of my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), the Hawke Labor socialist Government has now changed its mind. The Senate should be reminded of what I will refer to as open and complete disclosure in the form of papers that were presented to this chamber by the former Government upon request from this chamber in relation to bottom of the harbour schemes. A voluminous set of documents was presented, and some members of the then Opposition believed that they were being snowed by the volume of information by way of documents that was given to the Senate. A similar request was made by Senator Chipp but we find no more than a letter coming back explaining the situation in not very convincing terms.

In support of the legislation I also have a letter from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), who sent along the Kelly v. Raymor ( Illawarra) Pty Ltd case. This case gives some indication to the Senate of the blatently contrived schemes the Government is trying to prevent. The previous speaker, Senator Cook, referred to this sort of operation as a cherry picker scheme; in other words, the final beneficiaries were the directors. Let us look at the essential ingredients of this case. There is a superannuation fund, ostensibly a section 23F fund. The first clue to the Commissioner of Taxation, when he should say: 'Yes, we should be on the lookout', is a maximum contribution to the fund by the employer. That is the first signal that something may be wrong. The second clue is that the contribution is loaned back to the company, to the directors. These are disclosed in the superannuation returns and in the balance sheets that are presented with the company accounts. Again, the second clue is that there is no attempt by the trustee to discharge the duties towards the members. The third clue concerns a trustee being removed and another one being appointed-a sure sign that there is trouble. I submit that , as the letter says, there was a deliberate policy of keeping employees in the dark about the existence of their rights under the superannuation scheme. I submit that the Commissioner has not been doing his job and in not doing his job he has thrown the onus upon this Parliament to try to tidy up the mess for him.

All the signs were there. Let us go through the terms and conditions that are required under section 23F. Before doing so, I draw the attention of the Senate to Part IVA. It is a relatively new provision which came into being in the early 1980s. Part IVA was designed to replace an earlier provision which was designed to catch all tax evasion and avoidance measures that had escaped the tax collector's net as a result of a number of High Court decisions. We have not been given evidence by the Minister that Part IVA is not working in this area. We have not been given evidence that the Commissioner was doing everything in his power, by virtue of his having to look at and approve of the trust deed, and receive the annual accounts of the company and the accounts of the superannuation funds. He has seen what has been going on, but he has not been discharging his duty as required and as set down by the Act. I believe the Minister has a responsibility to convince the Senate--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Office was starved of staff for years by your Government.

—We have an interjection from the Minister at the table. He said that the Australian Taxation Office was starved of staff. If that is the reason, it is further proof that this legislation should not be before us today. All that the Commissioner has to do is to start to discharge his duties. A very interesting point was raised tonight by my colleague, Senator Hill, a lawyer. Why has not the Commissioner started to invoke section 170 of the Act where there has not been a full and true disclosure? Whichever way he tries to look at the matter, there are plenty of provisions in the Act which permit the Taxation Commissioner to take action in relation to these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned that I believe section 23F contains all the safeguards which are needed by the Commissioner to be able to discharge his duty. What has been said in this Parliament tonight would indicate that because of a lack of staff and for other reasons he has not sufficiently looked into and examined these superannuation schemes in approving them in the first place and then in not watching the progress of those superannuation schemes over the years. One of the conditions under section 23F is that there must be a communication to the employees to make sure that those employees' rights are safeguarded. I ask: What sort of piece of paper did the Taxation Commissioner ask the trustees of these funds to submit to him as proof that there had been adequate communication to the employees? We all know that bigger companies have a little book wherein the terms and conditions of the provident or superannuation fund are set out. The usual procedure with public companies is that this booklet is forwarded to the Taxation Commissioner. In relation to the private superannuation funds, which have probably not gone to the expense of having a written booklet produced, I ask: In those circumstances does the Commissioner sight a certified copy of that letter from the trustees to the employees? This was the worry of Senator Harradine in the debate tonight. He believes that it is all very well for the Taxation Commissioner to get his chop, but what about the employees? We see in the cherry picker scheme that has been referred to tonight that the rights of the employees have been totally forgotten.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a breach of trust.

—I wonder whether the employees should now be waking up to themselves and starting to sue the trustees. My colleague Senator Messner said that there has been a complete breach of trust. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Wool Industry Act 1972 to broaden the borrowing powers of the Australian Wool Corporation and to widen the opportunities for investment of Wool Research Trust Fund moneys. The present provisions of the Act limit the Corporation to borrowing moneys from an approved bank or another lender. Under clause 4 of the Bill the Corporation's borrowing powers are to be broadened, specifically to include power to deal in securities. The Bill also provides that the Commonwealth may provide appropriate guarantees in respect of such borrowings.

Clause 5 of the Bill repeals section 72 of the Act which specifies the investment options open to the Wool Research Trust Fund. The effect of this amendment is to make the Fund's investment procedure subject to the Audit Act which permits Commonwealth Trust Funds a broader range of investment options than is currently available to the Wool Research Trust Fund.

The Bill is consistent with the Government's policy to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of the operations of the primary industry statutory marketing authorities. The Australian Wool Corporation operates in an increasingly difficult and competitive environment and needs to be able to take advantage of the best borrowing rates available. To date, restrictions on the Corporation's borrowing powers have effectively limited its borrowings to term loans or overdrafts from banks. These sources of finance can be considerably more expensive than other avenues and impose unnecessary costs on woolgrowers. This is especially so at present when, because of depressed market conditions, the Corporation has had to borrow significant sums to finance the Reserve Price Scheme for wool.

The provisions of the Bill give the Corporation borrowing powers comparable with those of other major statutory authorities and place it in a position where it can commercially evaluate alternative sources of finance for its operations. In summary, the amendments proposed in the Bill will allow for better management of woolgrower funds for market support operations and for wool research. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Health seen the Royal Australian Chemical Institute report 'Why Doesn't Australia have a Research-Based Drug Industry'.
(2) What is the Government's reaction to the report and its recommendations.
(3) Will the Government set up a national medicinal and agro-chemical research and development council along similar lines to the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The Government has noted the report and recommendations with interest. A detailed submission on the matters raised is being developed by my Department.

The Government is aware of benefits that might arise from development of a national research-based drug industry and that many of the necessary resources exist in Australia. However, in any consideration of such a development, account will need to be taken of the difficulties in establishing a position in the international market, the very high cost of research required to develop a new drug and the need to assess expenditure in this area against other priorities.

The Industries Assistance Commission, in its 1976 report on pharmaceutical and veterinary products, noted the international character of the pharmaceutical industry, the concentration of research overseas and the relatively small size of the Australian market. The Commission considered that the local industry will continue to be predominantly based on compounding and packaging operations.

Because of the high cost of developing a new drug, currently about $100m, the limited market for many such products and intense overseas competition, development of a viable research-based industry in Australia would seem to require the active support of established pharmaceutical industry. The Government has undertaken to review its pricing policies for drugs available under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme this year. This review process will have regard to the influence these policies might have on encouraging pharmaceutical industry to support Australian-based drug research programs.

(3) The Government may consider establishment of a national medicinal and agro- chemical research council but the utility of such a body would need to be carefully appraised in view of the factors outlined above.
